Headline: Elbit Systems Reports Claim Filed Vs Co., ImageSat, Others
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   A claim has been filed by certain minority shareholders of ImageSat International N.V. against ImageSat, Israel Aerospace Industries Ltd., Elbit Systems Ltd. (ESLT) and certain current and former officers and directors of ImageSat.   Elbit said the claim, filed in a New York court, alleges the defendants "breached their fiduciary and/or contractual obligations to the detriment of the plaintiffs." The claim alleges various causes of action and damages aggregating "hundreds of millions of dollars."   ImageSat's largest shareholder is Isreal Aerospace, holding about 46% of ImageSat's outstanding shares. A subsidiary of Elbit holds about 14% of ImageSat. The former and current directors of ImageSat named as defendants include, among others, Michael Federmann, Joseph Ackerman and Joseph Gaspar, Elbit Systems' chairman, chief executive and chief financial Officer, respectively.   ImageSat operates satellites and provides satellite imagery.   Elbit Systems said it believes there is no merit to the allegations and considers the claims against it "baseless" and plans to "vigorously defend against them."   Elbit also said it believes the nature of the allegations provides a basis for counterclaims.   Elbit Systems is a defense-electronics company.   -Judy McKinnon; 416-306-2100; AskNewswires@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 10:45 ET (14:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 3rd UPDATE: Sportingbet's Bwin Tie-Up Talks Off, Shares Drop
Story: (This updates an article published at 1035 GMT with Bwin comments and background.)     By Lilly Vitorovich   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--Sportingbet PLC (SBT.LN) said Wednesday that tie-up talks with Bwin Interactive Entertainment AG (BWIN.IV) have been called-off, four months after the U.K.-listed online sports betting and gambling group confirmed it had received a preliminary bid approach.   In a brief two-sentence statement to the London Stock Exchange, Sportingbet said the talks "have now been mutually and amicably discontinued", triggering a sharp share drop.  No further details were provided by the group.   A Sportingbet spokesman told Dow Jones Newswires that talks were constructive but they couldn't find a middle ground. He declined to comment further.   The unstable regulatory environment in Europe, which has the online gambling sector under a cloud, made it impossible to agree on the terms of a merger, a Bwin spokesman said.     The decision comes two and half months after rivals, 888 Holdings PLC (888.LN) and Ladbrokes PLC (LAD.LN), called off similar tie-up talks amid the regulatory uncertainty and unexpected closure of the lucrative U.S. market last year.   888 took bets from U.S. customers prior to the government banning the sector, while Ladbrokes was mulling setting up online operations in the region. They were in tie-up talks for some seven months.   The Sportingbet announcement was expected among some industry observers and gaming analysts following growing uncertainty about the online gambling industry in Europe and Bwin's falling share price in recent months, Daniel Stewart & Co. analyst James Hollins said.   Some investors thought that Bwin's falling share price might have affected any deal involving Bwin securities, he noted.   There has been good institutional support for Sportingbet based on fundamentals of late, with the group doing well operationally, said Hollins, who is reinstating Sportingbet with a buy rating and 62 pence target price.   Daniel Stewart & Co. are house brokers to Sportingbet.   At 1242 GMT, Sportingbet shares were down 5 pence, or 8.1%, to 54 pence, valuing the group at GBP233.7 million, in a slightly higher London market. Bwin shares were up 2.8%  at EUR24.80 in a flat Vienna market.   Last month, Sportingbet posted a sharp rise in third-quarter group operating profit, and said it remained confident for the remainder of the financial year.   Stripping out exceptional charges, goodwill amortization and share option charges, group operating profit rose more than threefold to GBP3.0 million in the third quarter ended April 30 from GBP0.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The third-quarter result was underpinned by a strong performance in Sportingbet's core sports betting operations.   Group operating profit before exceptional items is the key figure U.K. investors and analyst track when assessing the group's operating performance.   Turnover from continuing operations rose to GBP291.1 million in the third-quarter from GBP229.4 million a year ago.   In order to aid comparison, the financial and operational information for the prior period is stated excluding the U.S. business, which was sold in October 2006, resulting in Sportingbet's exit from the market.    On March 7, Sportingbet confirmed it was in talks with Austria-based Bwin about the possible acquisition of Sportingbet in the wake of recent press speculation.     Company Web site: http://www.sportingbet.com                       http://www.bwin.com     -By Lilly Vitorovich, Dow Jones Newswires; 44-0-207 842 9290; lilly.vitorovich@dowjones.com     (Flemming Hansen in Vienna contributed to this story.)       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 08:52 ET (12:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Mexico Mining Union Plans 24-Hour Nationwide Walkout
Story: (Updates with comment from company official)     MEXICO CITY (Dow Jones)--Mexico's National Mining and Metal Workers Union plans to stage a 24-hour nationwide walkout Thursday unless labor authorities agree to address its demands over safety concerns at mines, a union official said Wednesday.   Carlos Pavon, the union's secretary of political affairs, said the planned walkout by "nearly all" of the union is set to start at 7 a.m. local time (1200 GMT) Thursday.   The union, which represents about 250,000 members, is also threatening to strike later this month at several facilities operated by Grupo Mexico (GMEXICO.MX), including the country's largest copper mine, Cananea, the zinc mine at Zacatecas and a smaller mine at Taxco, Pavon said.   The miners union, which has made most of its safety complaints against Grupo Mexico, is insisting the Labor Ministry get the company to sit down to negotiate its demands, Pavon added.   A Grupo Mexico official rejected the union charges about safety, saying the company is meeting standards at all of its facilities, and exceeding them in some.   The official said the effects of a one-day strike would probably be minimal, and would depend on the number of workers who decide to join in the stoppage. Many workers are reluctant to strike because they lose money.   Due to high world copper prices, Grupo Mexico recently paid out $130 million to workers in profit-sharing for 2006.     -By Anthony Harrup, Dow Jones Newswires; (5255) 5080 3450, anthony.harrup@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:04 ET (17:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Argentina Banco Galicia Delays $100M Cap Hike Subscription
Story: BUENOS AIRES (Dow Jones)--Argentina's Banco de Galicia y Buenos Aires (GALI.BA) said Wednesday that it postponed by 30 days the beginning of the subscription period for its announced $100-million capital increase.   The stock issuance is the latest phase of the bank's ongoing debt-restructuring plan, which can be subscribed either through cash or through outstanding Banco Galicia bonds due 2010, 2014 and 2019.   Banco Galicia is the primary asset of Grupo Financiero Galicia SA (GGAL), which owns 93.6% of its outstanding shares.     -By Serena Saitto, Dow Jones Newswires; 5411-4311-3125; serena.saitto@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 16:39 ET (20:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:EU Fines Telefonica EUR151.9M For Broadband Mkt Abuses
Story: (Updates an item that ran at 0945 GMT with company response, commission comments, further details)     BRUSSELS (Dow Jones)--The European Commission Wednesday fined Spain's Telefonica SA (TEF) EUR151.9 million, saying the telecommunications giant used its grip on the country's telephone network to hamper rival broadband providers.   Telefonica squeezed its competitors' margins by raising fees for access to its telephone network and lowering its own prices for retail broadband services, the commission said in a statement.   Telefonica was "making it virtually impossible for competitors to enter the market," the commission's top antitrust official, Neelie Kroes, told a news conference.   The commission's penalty, its highest ever against a telecommunications company, is part of a broader effort to shake up the sector, which is still dominated by former state-owned monopolies. Over the past year, the regulator has pressed operators to lower mobile phone roaming charges and has pushed for changes in several broadband markets. The commission last week took Germany to court for giving Deutsche Telekom AG (DT) a legal monopoly over the country's broadband network.   Telefonica's fine shows how the regulator is escalating its crackdown on antitrust abuses by levying heftier fines. In similar cases in 2003, Wanadoo, the Internet arm of France Telecom (FTE), was fined EUR10.4 million and Deutsche Telekom was penalized EUR12.6 million. In a range of recent collusion cases, fines have been several times larger than in comparable cases just a few years ago.     Kroes said Telefonica's fine was justified because of the seriousness of the abuse and the harm done to consumers. Spanish broadband customers pay 20% more than the average price in the 15 oldest E.U. member countries and Spain's broadband penetration rate is 20% lower than average, according to the commission.   Telefonica said it will appeal the fine, calling the commission's penalty "unjustified and disproportionate." It added that it has complied with rules established by Spain's telecommunications regulator.    "Telefonica finds itself squeezed between two regulators, the national regulator and the European Commission, which are at odds with each other," the company said in a statement.     Telefonica said its share of Spain's broadband market has decreased steadily to its current 55% from 95% in 2001. The company's main competitors for broadband services include Orange, a unit of France Telecom, and Jazztel PLC (JAZ.MC).   Being a former state-owned monopoly helped Telefonica rig Spain's broadband market, according to the commission. About 80% of high-speed Internet connections in Spain are made over fixed telephone lines. Telefonica, which was privatized in 1997, is the only Spanish telecommunications company with a nationwide fixed-line network.      The commission said that between September 2001 and December 2006, the margin between Telefonica's retail prices and the fees it charged for network access was too thin for other providers to cover their costs.   Telefonica's business plan and cost accounts show that the company "could not have been unaware that it was engaging in a margin squeeze," the commission said.   The E.U. regulator opened a formal investigation into Telefonica's business practices in February 2006. That prompted Spain's telecommunications authority to force the company to lower its wholesale prices in December 2006, ending the company's antitrust abuses, according to the commission.     -By Adam Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires; +322 741 1486; adam.cohen@dowjones.com   (Peppi Kiviniemi and Jason Sinclair contributed to this article)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 07:56 ET (11:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: IN THE MONEY: Movie Gallery's Covenant Crisis Redux
Story: By Michael Rapoport     A Dow Jones Newswires Column     (This article was originally published Tuesday)     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Movie Gallery Inc. (MOVI) just showed investors how dangerous it can be to ever again trust a company once it gets into serious trouble with its debt covenants.   The video-store chain said late Monday it had failed to meet two covenants, the financial thresholds required to certify to its lenders that it's healthy. If the breach isn't resolved, the company's creditors would be able to collect immediately on $1.2 billion in debt. The stock crashed Tuesday, losing nearly two-thirds of its value to close at 66 cents.   This crisis comes in the wake of similar trouble meeting covenant levels that plagued Movie Gallery last year - a problem that seemed to be resolved when the company refinanced its credit facility in February and reset its covenants to very lenient, easy-to-meet levels. Not so, apparently.   What this means, in part, is that Movie Gallery appears to have had a second quarter so atrocious that it couldn't even meet those ultra-relaxed covenant levels. Some back-of-the envelope calculations suggest Movie Gallery's operations may have produced less than half the cash earnings in the second quarter than they did in the year-ago period.   But this crisis is also a reminder that Movie Gallery hasn't done very well in forecasting the future of its business. That goes for many other companies that get into covenant trouble as well.   When a company has covenant problems by definition that means it's in danger of not meeting the performance requirements to which it had previously agreed. Even if the company survives the crisis and gets its covenant levels waived or relaxed, that inability to forecast the future - to be able to tell just what a business is capable of, and what thresholds it can meet - can lead it back into covenant trouble all over again. Investors should realize that and be wary.   A Movie Gallery spokeswoman declined to comment.   But a look at the numbers suggests just how dismal its recently completed second quarter must have been. The company said Monday its covenant breach was caused by "significantly softer-than-expected second-quarter results," and that may be an understatement.   Movie Gallery tripped two key covenants. One requires it to keep its "leverage ratio" - the ratio of its debt to its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization - within specified levels. The other requires the company to maintain a minimum level of "interest coverage," or Ebitda as a multiple of the interest payments on its debt.   The leverage ratio Movie Gallery must meet is debt of no more than 6.75 times the last four quarters' Ebitda - a very lenient level, and one the company easily met earlier this year. The fact that Movie Gallery can't stay below that level now, combined with its current debt and its announced Ebitda for the prior three quarters, imply its second-quarter Ebitda must have been no more than about $37 million, compared with the year-ago figure of $57.6 million. (These are rough, highly unofficial calculations, not sanctioned by the company.)   It gets even worse when you look at the interest-coverage covenant under which the past four quarters' Ebitda must be at least 1.4 times the past four quarters' interest payments. Even taking into account the interest savings the company expected from the February refinancing, it appears second-quarter Ebitda must have been no more than around $26 million if the company failed to meet the required interest-covenant level.   In other words, the fact that the company failed both covenants suggests that roughly $26 million - down 55% from a year ago - is the maximum level of Ebitda that Movie Gallery could have posted in the second quarter.   To be fair, the terrible performance isn't all Movie Gallery's fault. Conditions in the video-rental business have been dismal lately; the company said in its statement Monday that "we, like most of the industry, have experienced a sharp decline in our rental business" in recent months.   Last week, Movie Gallery's rival Blockbuster Inc. (BBI) estimated revenues from the domestic in-store rental industry - the only kind of video rental Movie Gallery does, since it doesn't have an online-rental program - fell 13% in the first half of 2007. Blockbuster also said it needed a break on its own covenants because the company has been spending a lot on a new online-rental program.   Then again, part of the poor performance is Movie Gallery's fault. A big part of the company's problems has been its ill-fated acquisition of Hollywood Entertainment Corp. in 2005, which never worked out the way Movie Gallery hoped it would.   Movie Gallery is holding a conference call with its lenders Tuesday to address its problems. The company says its business will continue without interruption, and that it plans cost-cutting moves, including possibly closing or consolidating stores. Longer term, Movie Gallery says it will consider a sale of the company, a recapitalization and other alternatives.   But that may not help investors who've bought Movie Gallery stock in recent months. And any other investors who think they see good value in a beaten-down company with covenant troubles may want to think twice.   (Michael Rapoport is one of four "In the Money" columnists who take a sophisticated look at the value of companies, and their securities, and explore unique trading strategies.)   -By Michael Rapoport, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-5976; michael.rapoport@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 07:30 ET (11:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJE(7/4) Breakingviews: Danone Should Beef Up
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE)   IT'S TIME FOR Groupe Danone to get into shape. Offloading its lagging biscuit division to Kraft Foods Inc. for a rich 5.3 billion euros ($7.2 billion) leaves the French consumer group as a pure play in the attractive dairy-products and beverages businesses, but there are still improvements to be made.   Top of the list: Danone needs to buy out as many of its partners as possible. The company's disastrous experience in China is a lesson. A spat with Zong Qinghou, its partner in China, has devastated Danone's promising business there. Danone's Indian experience is hardly more encouraging. There, it is locked in arbitration to end a biscuit partnership -- which Kraft isn't buying.   Danone may need to rebuild rather than buy out in these two promising markets, but it can move elsewhere. There are opportunities in the U.S., Colombia, Vietnam and Australia, where it has joint ventures. Getting full control would not only stave off the risk of problems from partners, it also would ensure that Danone shareholders get the full advantage of these markets. Danone could afford it, given the proceeds of the Kraft sale. If the partnerships' earnings justify Danone's current 22 multiple of estimated 2007 earnings, it would take about 4 billion euros to buy them all out.   Then there are acquisitions. With a successful brand and image to support it, Danone has plenty of options. Dutch baby-food maker Royal Numico, with a market capitalization of 7.6 billion euros, has been called a natural extension to the group's franchises. Wimm-Bill-Dann, a $3.4 billion juice and dairy group with a leading position in Russia, also would fit. Danone already owns an 18% stake.   Sure, the money from Kraft won't stretch far enough for Danone to reconfigure its portfolio entirely, but Danone was sitting on an unleveraged balance sheet even without selling its biscuits. It could gear up by a further 10 billion euros and still have debt at a fairly conservative 25% of enterprise value. Add that to the 5.3 billion euros from Kraft and that leaves the French with more than 15 billion euros. For a 32 billion euros company, that's a lot of money to play with.   If Danone boss Franck Riboud spends wisely, investors will become even more enthusiastic about Danone's prospects. That might be more credible than any arbitrary government protections.     SAP/Oracle     SAP AG has suffered an embarrassing setback in its competition against Oracle Corp. The German software company was forced to acknowledge that its U.S. subsidiary, TomorrowNow, downloaded documents and software patches from Oracle without permission. SAP will pay thrice for this transgression.   The likely direct effect is small. SAP probably will pay a fine or settlement to end Oracle's lawsuit. The figure is unlikely to exceed $100 million, according to Citigroup Inc. research. If so, it would be a slap on the wrist, considering Oracle's market capitalization is more than $60 billion.   The indirect effects will hurt more. Oracle and its boss, Larry Ellison, always have had a swashbuckling image. SAP, by contrast, has been perceived as solidly earnest, if a bit plodding. Its admission of wrongdoing tarnishes that reputation, and the longer the suit drags on, the more damage potentially done.   SAP's confession also hurts its TomorrowNow unit, which services Oracle software on the cheap. While the unit booked only $16 million of revenue last year, it was potentially a big threat to Mr. Ellison's company. That's because Oracle gets more revenue from maintaining its applications than from selling new ones. It and similar groups increasingly act like razor companies, peddling discounted handles in the hope of selling lots of recurring, high-margin blades. So a discount competitor could cut into Oracle's margins.   SAP says it is beefing up TomorrowNow, but clients undoubtedly will wonder about the quality of the unit's service if it needed to resort to pilfering Oracle's proprietary materials. The odds that SAP can wound Oracle's cash cow now look smaller, and that's by far the biggest damage caused by the scandal.     New Look     New Look Group PLC was for a while the poster child of U.K. leveraged buyouts. In recent days, though, it seems to have lost some of its looks. Owners Apax Partners and Permira have failed to get their GBP 1.8 billion ($3.6 billion) reserve price in an auction of the U.K. retailer, which they bought in 2004 for GBP 700 million. The bidders were reluctant to pay more than GBP 1.7 billion, according to people familiar with the situation, and the auction was disbanded.   It's hard to see why the buyout groups wouldn't just take the cash. A price of GBP 1.8 billion would put New Look on roughly the same multiple, based on earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, as U.K. high-street stalwart Marks & Spencer. New Look has been growing at breakneck speed, but the durability of that growth is unproven. Cheap fashion is a volatile business. That makes GBP 1.7 billion look hardly stingy.   Second, New Look's appeal has been diminished by the clumsiness of the auction process. An asking price of GBP 2 billion was bandied about in the press, then talked down. Rumored buyers never materialized. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. even went to the unusual length of denying on the record that it was acting as a principal in a bid. Future bidders can use these stumbles as negotiating tools.   Apax and Permira probably will refinance New Look and try to sell it, but even if they juice up the debt to seven times New Look's Ebitda for last year and sell for GBP 1.8 billion in a year's time, the net present value of their takings would be GBP 630 million -- only GBP 30 million more than they could have gotten this time round.   -- Una Galani, Robert Cyran and John Foley   ---   For more commentary, go to www.breakingviews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 00:30 ET (04:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : AGF Continues Record Setting Pace For Mutual Fund Sales In June>AGF.B.T
Story: TORONTO, July 4 /CNW/ - AGF Management Limited (AGF) again broke a record for sales reporting gross sales of long-term funds of $492.9 million for the month of June 2007. This represents the highest gross sales for any month of June in the history of the company. Net sales of long-term funds for the month ended June 30, 2007 were $172.2 million.    "June was another strong month for mutual funds sales and we are very appreciative of the support of our clients," said Blake Goldring, chairman and chief executive officer, AGF Management Limited, "We will continue to focus our organization on investment management, relationship management and product management."          <<      -------------------------------------------------------------------------      ($ millions)  Assets at  Gross Sales  Redemptions  Net Sales   Net Sales                    June 30/07   June 2007   June 2007   June 2007   June 2006      -------------------------------------------------------------------------      Long-term       funds           30,013       492.9       320.7       172.2      (11.9)      -------------------------------------------------------------------------      Money market        474        12.5        16.9        (4.4)      (4.2)      -------------------------------------------------------------------------      Total mutual       funds           30,487       505.4       337.6       167.8      (16.1)      -------------------------------------------------------------------------      Institutional +       private client  24,310      -------------------------------------------------------------------------      Total Assets     54,797      -------------------------      >>      Average daily mutual fund AUM for June 2007 were $30.7 billion. AGF institutional and private client AUM grew 73.6% to $24.3 billion up from $14.0 billion one year ago. Institutional and private client assets are up due to investment performance, new mandates and the acquisition of 80% of Highstreet Partners Limited. Total fee-earning AUM, including mutual funds, institutional mandates and private client were $54.8 billion up 45.7% from $37.6 billion for the same period last year.    Sales of AGF's international funds remain strong as Canadians are committing more investment dollars outside of Canada. Net sales of international equity funds for the month ended June 30, 2007 were $79.2 million.    AGF has worked diligently to provide tailored products to suit client needs. During the month of June, AGF announced the addition of a new Harmony Balanced Growth Portfolio made up of 60% equities and 40% fixed income, complementing its six other distinct Harmony portfolios.    AGF also looks for opportunities to offer investment management services to clients by working with business partners. Starting on June 11, 2007, advisors were able to purchase seven-year principal-protected notes, offered by CIBC, that are linked to the performance of the award-winning AGF International Stock Class. Building on the original series that closed earlier in June, the CIBC AGF International Stock Class Deposit Notes Series 2 provides conservative investors with access to international markets within the safety of principal-protected notes.    AGF continually builds on the rigour and discipline of its investment management process. This has resulted in impressive investment performance. AGF had 59% of its assets in the first quartile for the 1-year period ending May 31, 2007.    About AGF Management Limited    AGF Management Limited is one of Canada's premier investment management companies with offices across Canada and subsidiaries around the world. 2007 marks AGF's 50th anniversary of providing Canadians with innovative investment solutions across the wealth continuum. AGF's products and services include a diversified family of more than 50 mutual funds, the evolutionary AGF Elements portfolios, the Harmony asset management program, AGF Private Investment Management, Institutional Account Services and AGF Trust GICs, loans and mortgages. With approximately $55 billion in total assets under management, AGF serves more than one million investors. AGF trades on the Toronto Stock Exchange under the symbol "AGF.B".             /CONTACT: AGF Management Limited shareholders and analysts, please contact: Adrian Basaraba, Vice President, Finance and Investor Relations, (416) 865-4203, adrian.basaraba@AGF.com; Media, please contact: Lucy Becker, Vice President, Corporate Communications, (416) 865-4284, lucy.becker@AGF.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:32 ET (17:32 GMT)

Headline: Canada Afternoon: C$ Ends Higher In Illiquid Trading
Story: TORONTO (Dow Jones)--The Canadian dollar ended higher in mostly illiquid dealings Wednesday, as supportive factors for the currency such as strong commodity prices and merger and acquisition-related demand for the currency remained in force despite thinned-out markets due to the U.S. July 4th holiday.   The U.S. dollar was trading at C$1.0582at 3:20 p.m. EDT (1920 GMT), from C$1.0580 at 8:00 a.m. EDT (1200 GMT), and from C$1.0612 late Tuesday.   Movements for the Canadian dollar were restricted to a tight C$1.0560-C$1.0620 range Wednesday, as new trading incentives and market breadth were both lacking given the close of U.S. financial markets for Independence Day.   The Canadian dollar's modest gains Wednesday were generally due to technical factors, and also reflected sustained positive sentiment toward the currency from the corporate M&A perspective, and also given the recent rise of crude oil prices comfortably above the $70 per barrel mark.   "The Canadian dollar remains strong as the commodities remain bid," said Firas Askari, managing director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in Toronto. "And the belief is that while some of the significant M&A deals have already transpired, there's still more in the pipeline, so people are happy buyers of Canadian dollars on any moves toward the C$1.10620-C$1.0650 area."   When fuller trading resumes on Thursday, the Canadian dollar could remain somewhat rangebound however, as currency players await Friday's June employment report, the last piece of significant domestic economic data prior to next Tuesday's Bank of Canada interest rate announcement.   These are the exchange rates at 3:20 p.m. EDT (1920 GMT), 8:00 a.m. EDT (1200 GMT), and late Tuesday.     USD/CAD     1.0582     1.0580     1.0612     EUR/CAD     1.4408     1.4412     1.4440     CAD/JPY     115.95     115.72     115.39   -Paul Evans; Dow Jones Newswires; 416-306-2022; paulr.evans@dowjones.com       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 15:22 ET (19:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: REPEAT&CORRECT: =THE SKEPTIC: The High Price Of Hotels
Story: ("=THE SKEPTIC: The High Price of Hotels," published at 1324 GMT, misstated the forward earnings multiple of  Blackstone's offer for the Hilton Hotel Group.)     By Sean Walters   A DOW JONES NEWSWIRES COLUMN     LONDON (Dow Jones)--It could be open season on hotel groups after Blackstone's shot at the sector with a $26-billion bid for the Hilton Hotel Group.   But this deal, and any more that may come in the hotel sector, comes at the top of the market. It's hard to see good fundamental reasons for valuations to go much higher when the sector is already benefiting from unusually favorable conditions.   So private-equity buzz may not be enough to sustain the share-price gains triggered by the Blackstone bid. Intercontinental Hotels shares were up over 5% and Accor's were up 7% Wednesday.   But both companies have seen strong-price gains in the past year, with Accor up 48% and Intercontinental up 35%.   That's left the two companies' stock trading at around a median multiple for the sector of 21X estimated 2008 earnings. That's hardly a bargain-basement valuation - but then consider Blackstone's offer that values Hilton at around 31X estimated 2008 earnings.   Of course, Blackstone isn't the only private-equity firm to have seen the sector's potential. Colony Capital is a key shareholder in Accor where it forced a management shakeup last year and a shift in the company's strategy.   And you can see why there is so much interest. The hotel sector is enjoying a spectacular boom.   Buoyant real-estate markets worldwide are inflating hotel property values - up 9.4% in Europe in 2006 - pushing up average hotel-room values.   London tops the list in Europe with an average room value of EUR677,000, while the European average has hit a 14-year high at EUR252,000.   But the trade is doing well too.   Take Accor whose 2007 first quarter results, traditionally the weakest quarter in the hotel industry, showed like for like revenues from hotels up 7.2%, the strongest growth in the past ten years.   The upscale segment of its European hotel operation generated a revenue per available room up 13%, building on an already strong 2006 performance.   At Intercontinental, 2006 revenue per available room rose 9.8% even as it expanded aggressively, predicting it'll exceed its target of opening 60,000 new rooms by the end of 2008.   But therein lies the risk of future overcapacity and a squeeze on profits that the companies' frothy stock-market ratings don't seem to be discounting, particularly as monetary policy tightens globally, as well as the possibility of economic shocks that might hit the sector.   Investors have already discounted improved returns as the hotel groups dispose of their property portfolios to focus on being asset-light service companies. Cash from the sales can be used for acquisitions or returned to investors.   Now, Blackstone's bid for Hilton was at a 40% premium to the previous day's closing price, an impressive sign of the  further value that some investors are expecting from these companies.   But this may prove to be as good as it gets.     (Sean Walters, the newest member of Dow Jones Newswires' Skeptic team, has previously consulted on such areas as operational strategy, marketing and finance. He can be reached at +44 20 7842 9251 or by e-mail: sean.walters@dowjones.com)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 12:40 ET (16:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Roche Files Complaint Against Ventana's Poison Pill
Story: ZURICH (Dow Jones)--Roche Holding AG (RHHBY) Wednesday said it has filed a complaint against "the poison pill" of U.S.-based Ventana Medical Systems Inc. (VMSI), for which the Swiss drug maker launched a $3 billion hostile takeover offer in June.   "The complaint is a technical step as many companies do have poison pills in their statutes that allow them to fend off hostile takeovers", Roche spokesman Daniel Piller said.   "Usually such complaints are filed together with the offer," he said.   Poison pills can be manifold. Companies can have golden shares that block a competitor from a takeover or they can allow management to issue new shares and thus block an unfriendly takeover bid.   Company Web Site:http://www.roch.com   -By Goran Mijuk, Dow Jones Newswires, +41 43 443 80 47, goran.mijuk@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 12:46 ET (16:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Brazil's Tarpon Investment Raises BRL443.8M From IPO
Story: SAO PAULO (Dow Jones)-Brazil's investment funds administrator, Tarpon Investment Group (TARP11.BR), raised a total of 443.8 million Brazilian reals ($232.3 million) from its initial public offering, more than the BRL400 million initially announced, the company said Wednesday.   Tarpon said that the initial value of the IPO increased after it offered an extra lot of shares to attend the strong demand.   The company sold 20.17 million shares, with 18.25 million acquired by foreign investors.   Credit Suisse Group (CS) was the lead coordinator of the offer.   Tarpon sold each of its shares in the IPO at BRL22.00. On Tuesday, the company's shares ended quoted at BRL21.63 on the local stock exchange, the Bovespa.   Tarpon was the second investment fund administrator to list its shares on the Bovespa. In June 2006, GP Investments, South America's largest investment funds administrator, raised a total of BRL706 million from its IPO on the Bovespa.   Tarpon was created in June, 2002, and oversees an equity fund worth BRL1.4 billion, according to information on the company's website.     -By Rogerio Jelmayer, Dow Jones Newswires; 5511-3145-1480; rogerio.jelmayer@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 06:55 ET (10:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UAE IPIC Invites Bids For Fujairah Crude Export Pipeline
Story: DUBAI (Dow Jones)--International Petroleum Investment Co., an Abu Dhabi government investment firm, said Wednesday it invited six companies to bid for the contract to build a pipeline for crude oil export from the United Arab Emirates' east coast.   Technip S.A., Chicago Bridge & Iron Co. N.V. and WorleyParsons Ltd. are among the companies invited to bid for the early engineering contract to build the 360-kilometer pipeline, which will run from Abu Dhabi to the U.A.E. emirate of Fujairah, IPIC said in a statement.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 06:44 ET (10:44 GMT)

Headline: Ecuador Govt Studies Suggestion To End Petrobras Operations
Story: By Mercedes Alvaro   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     QUITO (Dow Jones)--Ecuador's acting Energy Minister Jorge Alban said Wednesday he's studying a panel report that recommends that the cancellation of the operations of Brazil's state-run oil firm Petroleo Brasileiro SA (PBR), or Petrobras, in the Andean country.   The report accuses Petrobras of a series of irregularities. A commission of union and oil-worker representatives wrote the report that was ordered by the energy ministry.   "I only received the report yesterday from the commission," Alban told Dow Jones Newswires in a telephone interview. "We are analyzing it with a team of technicians to undertand its legal and technical aspects."   Petrobras press officials in Rio de Janeiro said the company only knows about the issue through the press and has no immediate comment.   Petrobras produces about 35,000 barrels of oil a day in Ecuador.Company plans to expand its output in the Andean country have been delayed by environmental snags.   Alban said he could neither confirm nor exclude the possibility that his government will cancel Petrobras' contracts.   "It's premature to talk about the issue," Alban said. "Depending on the analysis (of the report), a decision will be made." He couldn't say how long it would take for the government to study the report.   Ecuador last year canceled a contract with Occidental Petroleum Co. (OXY) after accusing the U.S. oil firm of wrongdoings, among them the unauthorized transfer of a 40% stake in its operations in Ecuador to Canadian oil firm Encana Corp. (ECA). Occidental Petroleum is seeking international arbitration over the decision.   The panel report makes similar charges against Petrobras, among them, it sold 40% of its stake in Ecuador's block 18 and Palu Azul oil fields to Japanese oil firm Teikoku Oil, without the proper authorization.   In January 2005, Petrobras signed a preliminary contract over the sale and  cooperation with the Japanese firm, and a separate 40% stake in private heavy oil pipeline OCP.   Petrobras later communicated its intention to sell the stakes to the stock market regulator of the Buenos Aires stock exchange, although approval by Ecuadorean government was still pending.   In Ecuador, Petrobras is part of the company's Argentine subsidiary Petrobras Energia (PESA.BA), which is listed on the Buenos Aires stock exchange.   Unions for Ecuador's state-owned oil firm Petroecuador and left-wing social groups have repeatedly demanded the government expel Petrobras from Ecuador.   Having read the report as well before stepping down from his post on June 13, Ecuador's former Energy Minister Alberto Acosta wrote a letter to President Rafael Correa, recommending considering possible sanctions and possibly ending Petrobras' operations contract.     -By Mercedes Alvaro, Dow Jones Newswires; 5939-9728-653; mercedes.alvaro@dowjones.com   (Bernd Radowitz in Rio de Janeiro contributed to this report.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:59 ET (17:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: BHP Extends Chile GasAtacama Pipeline Bailout -Report
Story: SANTIAGO (Dow Jones)--Diversified natural resources giant BHP Billiton Ltd. (BHP) extended its partial bailout of Chilean power generator and natural gas pipeline operator GasAtacama beyond September, Diario Financiero newspaper reported Wednesday.   The bailout is part of an agreement by which investment fund Southern Cross will buy the 50% stake CMS Energy Corp.(CMS) put on the auction block, Diego Hernandez, head of BHP Billiton's Base Metals Division, told the newspaper.   "Yes, that's it; paying for our contracts and helping out in an important fashion so that the company doesn't suffer losses with its regulated clients," Hernandez said, the newspaper reported.   In early June, BHP Billiton and state mining giant Corporacion Nacional del Cobre de Chile, or Codelco, bailed out GasAtacama with some $20 million, which helped the pipeline cover its losses on lower power rates with regulated clients.   Hernandez declined to detail how much it had paid GasAtacama in the second bailout, but he said he hopes other mining clients will also contribute to cover GasAtacama's financial woes.   GasAtacama, a joint venture between U.S.-based CMS Energy Corp. (CMS) and Chilean power Empresa Nacional de Electricidad (EOC), or Endesa, is going through a financial crisis as a result of Argentina's decision to reduce its natural gas exports.   Earlier this year, CMS opted to to sell its 50% stake in GasAtacama to Ashmore Energy International for a total of $80 million. Endesa, however, had a preferential option for the stake and last weekend announced it decided to transfer that option to investment fund Southern Cross.   Nevertheless, Southern Cross conditioned its GasAtacama acquisition to mining companies covering the losses from regulated, or residential, clients, Endesa said over the weekend in a filing with the local securities overseer.   While the company renegotiated terms with most of its unregulated clients, namely the large copper mining companies in northern Chile, it hasn't been able to pass its higher costs onto its regulated, residential clients, which represent 45% of its income. Currently, the company is waiting to solve a dispute with a power distributor before modifying its residential rates.   There is practically no hydroelectric generation on the SING grid, and the system relies on coal and natural gas-fired generators.   Since 2004, Argentina has reduced its natural gas exports to Chile to ensure it can meet domestic demand.   Although Argentina has plentiful supplies of gas, caps on prices have dissuaded companies from ramping up production. Over the past weeks, Argentina has deepened the cuts, forcing Chilean generators and industries to operate solely on diesel.   Analysts expect generators and industries to continue paying higher fuel costs at least until 2009, when two government-backed liquified natural gas re-gasification plants come on line in northern and central Chile.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.diariofinanciero.cl     -By Patricia San Juan, Dow Jones Newswires 56-2-460-8546 patty.sanjuan@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:10 ET (17:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : OPTI Canada To Host 2Q 2007 Conference Call On July 13, 2007>OPC.T
Story: CALGARY, July 4 /CNW/ - OPTI Canada Inc. (OPTI) announced today that it will conduct a conference call at 7:00 a.m. Mountain Time (9:00 a.m. Eastern Time) on Friday, July 13, 2007 to review the Company's second quarter 2007 financial and operating results. Sid Dykstra, President and Chief Executive Officer, and David Halford, Chief Financial Officer, will host the call. To participate in the conference call, dial:    (866) 249-1964 (North American Toll-Free)    (416) 644-3414 (Alternate)    Please reference the OPTI Canada conference call with Sid Dykstra when speaking with the Operator.    A replay of the call will be available until July 27, 2007, inclusive. To access the replay, call (416) 640-1917 or 1-877-289-8525 and enter passcode 21236609, followed by the pound sign.    This call will also be webcast, and can be accessed on OPTI Canada's website under "Presentations and Webcasts" in the "For Investors" section. The webcast will be available for replay through August 13, 2007. The webcast may also be accessed at:    http://phx.corporate-ir.net/playerlink.zhtml?c=178509&s=wm&e=1592323.    About OPTI    OPTI Canada Inc. is a Calgary, Alberta-based company focused on developing the fourth and next major integrated oil sands project in Canada, the Long Lake Project, in a 50/50 joint venture with Nexen Inc. The first phase of the Project consists of 72,000 barrels per day of SAGD (steam assisted gravity drainage) oil production integrated with an OPTI-operated upgrading facility, using OPTI's proprietary OrCrude(TM) process and commercially available hydrocracking and gasification. Through gasification, this configuration substantially reduces the exposure to and the need to purchase natural gas. The Project is expected to produce 58,500 bbl/d of products, primarily 39 degree API Premium Sweet Crude with low sulphur content, making it a highly desirable refinery feedstock. OPTI's common shares trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange under the symbol OPC.    Additional information regarding the Long Lake Project is available at http://www.longlake.ca. Headline: : Strategic Energy Fund (TSX:SEF.UN) Announces Monthly Distribution Of C$0.08 Per Unit For July 2007>SEF.UN.T
Story: TORONTO, ONTARIO and CALGARY, ALBERTA--(CCNMatthews - July 4, 2007) - Strategic Energy Management Corp. announces that Strategic Energy Fund's (the "Fund") (TSX:SEF.UN) cash distribution for July 2007 will be C$0.08 per unit.      The distribution details are as follows:    =--------------------------------------------------------------------------  Distribution       Ex-distribution date       Record date      Payable date  =--------------------------------------------------------------------------  C$0.08 per unit           July 13, 2007     July 17, 2007     July 31, 2007  =--------------------------------------------------------------------------      Strategic Energy Fund    Strategic Energy Fund is an investment trust that seeks to provide unitholders with superior rates of return through a diversification strategy focused on investment opportunities within the Canadian energy sector. The Fund invests in established companies, early-stage energy companies and, to a lesser extent, special energy issuers, each with prospects for high growth in the near to medium term and the potential for long-term capital appreciation.    The Fund's investments in established companies, including energy royalty and income trusts, are made with a view to generate sufficient income to permit the Fund to make monthly cash distributions to unitholders.    Investments in early-stage energy companies are focused on both private and public issuers with strong, experienced management teams that have proven track records of enhancing shareholder value and successfully executing exit strategies. As well, the Fund may invest in undervalued issuers where Sentry Select Capital Corp., the investment advisor to the Fund, believes that capital appreciation can be realized.    Trading information    Strategic Energy Fund units trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange ("TSX") under the symbol SEF.UN.    Sentry Select Capital Corp.    Sentry Select is a Canadian wealth management company that manages over $8.5 billion in gross assets as of June 30, 2007. The company offers a diverse range of investment products including closed-end trusts, mutual funds, principal-protected notes and flow-through limited partnerships, covering a variety of domestic and global mandates. With 29 reporting issuers, Sentry Select Capital Corp. is the leading manager and/or advisor to entities listed on the TSX. Headline: Cosmo, Idemitsu To Export Oil Products To US - Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Cosmo Oil Co. (5007.TO) and Idemitsu Kosan Co. (5019.TO) are exporting petroleum products such as gasoline and kerosene to the U.S., where insufficient refinery capacity is causing prices to soar, The Nikkei reported in its Thursday morning edition.   The Japanese oil industry is believed to have crude oil refining capabilities that exceed demand by about 800,000 barrels a day. This is roughly 5% of the amount of crude refined in the U.S. so a move by other Japanese oil distributors to ship oil products to the U.S. may help to alleviate the shortage there.   Cosmo, which has secured its own unloading tanks in the suburbs of Los Angeles, began selling diesel fuel that complies with the state's standards to local retailers through long-term deals in April. Before that, it had only sold to U.S. oil companies through spot deals.   By engaging in wholesale business, Cosmo hopes to roughly triple exports to the U.S. from the previous fiscal year to 700,000 kiloliters this fiscal year, which is equivalent to 2% of the amount it sells at home.   Idemitsu plans to set up a sales office in Los Angeles by September. It intends to start exporting diesel and kerosene after securing receiving tanks locally. It also plans to install pipelines that connect to facilities where the products are handed over to retailers.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:49 ET (17:49 GMT)

Headline: Phonak May Buy ReSound Outside Germany Or Scrap Deal- Report
Story: ZURICH (Dow Jones)--Swiss hearing aid maker Phonak Holding AG (PHNB.EB) still hopes to take over 100% of rival ReSound, but may also settle for its operations outside Germany due to regulatory crossfire, Phonak chief executive Valentin Chapero told twice-weekly Finanz und Wirtschaft.   "The most stable solution would probably be to exclude ReSound Germany from the merger. Other international regulators have already approved the deal," Chapero said, adding the takeover price may have to be renegotiated in such a case.   Chapero added that Phonak may call the deal off altogether should the current uncertainty persist.   Earlier this year, Phonak appealed a ruling by Germany's antitrust body blocking the planned takeover of ReSound, a unit of Denmark's GN Store Nord (GN.KO), for CHF3.3 billion ($2.7 billion).   The court decision is due around Aug. 1.   Newspaper Web Site: http://www.finanzinfo.ch     -Zurich Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 8040; zurichdjnews@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 02:06 ET (06:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Mercedes Car Grp June Car Sales -1.3% On Yr >DCX
Story: Edited Press Release     FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX) said Wednesday that its Mercedes Car Group unit sold 117,200 Mercedes-Benz, Maybach and Smart brand passenger vehicles in June 2007, down 1.3% compared to 118,800 units in the same month last year.   A total of 617,700 units were sold in the first half of the year, down 1.5% from 627,300 last year.   The Mercedes-Benz brand set a new record for the month of June by delivering 107,300 vehicles to customers, up 1% from 106,200 in June last year.   Mercedes-Benz also posted record sales of 575,700 units over the first six months of the year, up 1.8% from 565,300 in the same period last year.   The company said that the new-generation E-Class performed extremely well during the period of January to June 2007. Sales of the upper-range model series totaled 120,100 units in the first half of the year, up 10% from the same period last year.   The Mercedes-Benz C-Class sedan met with a tremendous response from customers in the first three months after its market launch. A total of 22,800 C-Class sedans were sold in June, which represents a 41% increase from June 2006. The new C-Class sedan will be successively introduced to the U.S., Japan, and right-hand drive markets over the next few months. Mercedes-Benz will also begin offering three additional engine variants for the model in August: the C 180, C 230, and C 200 cdi.   Sales of Mercedes-Benz sport-utility-vehicles also continue to rise strongly. In the first six months of 2007, deliveries of the brand's SUVs worldwide rose 13% to the record level of 86,500 units.   After focusing on the Smart Fortwo, the brand delivered 9,900 vehicles last month, down 21% from 12,600 last year. Delieveries in the first half of the year fell 32% to 42,000 vehicles.       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 09:10 ET (13:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: MARKET TALK: Pali Keeps Buy On WH Smith, 500P Target
Story: 0909 GMT [Dow Jones] Pali International's Nick Bubb retains WH Smith (SMWH.LN) at buy with a 500p target despite being out of favor with investors. "The shares have slipped below 400p, disappointingly and remain out of favor, in an out of favor sector, despite the group's defensive strengths," Bubb says. "The airport security problems of last summer have been repeated in recent days, but it should be noted that last August's disruption turned out to be good for WH Smith's lucrative Airport shops, because of increased passenger dwell times, landside and airside," he adds. WH Smith +1.6% at 404p. Headline: Credit Agricole Interested In Intesa Sanpaolo Branches -2-
Story: Analysts estimate the value of the 198 branches at around EUR1.5 billion.   In December, Italy's antitrust authority gave conditional approval to the merger between Banca Intesa SpA and Sanpaolo Imi SpA, now Intesa Sanpaolo SpA, saying they would have to sell a total of 748 branches.   Last year, in order to comply with this, the majority of those branches were sold to Credit Agricole for EUR6 billion. Credit Agricole also bought two Italian regional retail banks.   Credit Agricole had owned almost 18% of Intesa and bought its regional branches in return for waiving its veto of Intesa's merger with Sanpaolo. It currently holds around 5% of Intesa-Sanpaolo.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 10:33 ET (14:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Honey, we Need to Talk - With my Nokia Speakerphone HF-300
Story: ESPOO, Finland, July 4 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Having a conversation in and out of the car is about as simple as talking to yourself, thanks to Nokia's first speakerphone, the stylish Nokia Speakerphone HF-300. This detachable Bluetooth speakerphone hosts a powerful speaker and microphone. Its audio quality is enhanced even more with Digital Signal Processing (DSP), canceling out excess noises and echoes. No need to concern yourself with the power button - this clever device knows when to turn off (auto power off) after you stop talking.     "We are committed to providing convenient communications in the car - and out of it too. The beauty of the Nokia Speakerphone HF-300 is in its mobility, it goes where you go, when you want to talk. We are excited to have the speakerphone as part of our expanding enhancements portfolio to meet the needs of our consumers," said Wolfgang Gartner, senior category manager, Nokia Automotive.     The Nokia Speakerphone HF-300 offers a number of elements that enable easy communications, in and out of the car. It is operated with battery power, so you're not confined to using it with a power outlet. The speakerphone comes with a sun visor clip, so you can easily position it for use in the car. You can talk freely too - the speakerphone has illuminated keys for easy use, without all the fuss of blinking lights. For those extended conversations, take this lightweight (80g) speakerphone outside, into your home or office, and mount it to a surface with its rubber feet. You can enjoy up to 20 hours of talk time!     The speakerphone will automatically turn off after five minutes after the connection to the mobile device has been severed. When the battery runs low, the LED battery indicator will light up to alert you.     Available globally, the Nokia Speakerphone HF-300 is compatible with a wide range of Nokia mobile devices supporting Bluetooth Specification 1.1 and higher and Handfree Profile 1.0 and higher. It is expected to be available in the third quarter of 2007 and will cost an estimated EUR90, excluding taxes.        About Nokia     Nokia (NYSE: NOK) is the world leader in mobility, driving the transformation and growth of the converging Internet and communications industries. Nokia makes a wide range of mobile devices and provides people with experiences in music, navigation, video, television, imaging, games and business mobility through these devices. Nokia also provides equipment, solutions and services for communications networks.        Related photos in print quality can be found at www.nokia.com/press    www.nokia.com    SOURCE  Nokia       /CONTACT: Media Enquiries: Nokia, Multimedia Communications, Tel. +358-7180-45751. Nokia Communications, Tel. +358-7180-34900, Email: press.office@nokia.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 03:19 ET (07:19 GMT)

Headline: Russia Lower House OKs Armed Security Forces For Pipelines
Story: MOSCOW (AP)--Lawmakers voted Wednesday to give Russia's natural-gas and oil pipeline monopolies the right to set up armed security units to protect the country's energy infrastructure.   One lawmaker said the move could lead to "a multitude of corporate armies."   Instead of hiring private security firms, state-controlled gas giant OAO Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS) and oil pipeline monopoly OAO Transneft (TRNFP.RS) would be able to directly arm and recruit their own security forces, under a bill passed by the lower parliament house, the State Duma.   To become law it must be approved by the upper house, the Federation Council, and signed by President Vladimir Putin.   Gazprom, the world's biggest gas producer, controls Russia's main gas pipelines and is the only company allowed to handle exports. Transneft, which is also state-run, has the monopoly on oil pipelines.   Lawmaker Gennady Gudkov, who opposed the bill, warned that it could open a "Pandora's Box."   State-controlled giants like savings bank Sberbank (SBER.RS), electricity utility UES and the railways monopoly could all seek the same right, he said.   "As a result there will soon be a multitude of corporate armies in the country," Gudkov said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 14:50 ET (18:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Rosneft Hires Banks For Benchmark Loan Participation Note
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Russian state-owned oil company OAO Rosneft (ROSN.RS) has hired ABN Amro, Barclays Capital, BNP Paribas, Calyon, Citigroup, JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley as joint lead managers and joint bookrunners for a benchmark-size loan participation note, one of the lead managers said Wednesday.   The transaction will be documented under Rosneft's $15 billion medium-term note program.   The deal is expected to launch and price following investor meetings in the U.S. and Europe scheduled to run from July 6 to July 12.   Earlier Wednesday, the Rosneft board approved a bond offering of up to $5 billion in either dollars or other currencies.    Rosneft borrowed $22 billion earlier this year to buy nearly all of what was left of OAO Yukos (YUKO.RS) at the time of its liquidation. Late last month, Rosneft said that it had received $9.2 billion from the liquidators of Yukos and that it would use the entire amount to retire portions of its debt.   Moody's Investors Service upgraded Rosneft's debt rating to Baa1 from Baa2 and assigned a Baa1 rating to the proposed $15 billion unsecured loan participation notes program and its first issue. It also assigned all the company's ratings a stable outlook.   The upgrade came only two days after Fitch Ratings had upgraded Rosneft's debt to BBB- from BBB+ and assigned the planned Eurobond issue a BBB- rating.     -By Michael Wilson, Dow Jones Newswires; 44 20 7842 9349; michael.wilson@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 12:54 ET (16:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Tesco: 78 Stores,50 Gas Stations In Hungary By End 07 -Agency
Story: BUDAPEST (Dow Jones)--Food retailer Tesco PLC (TSCO.LN) expects by the end of this year to have boosted its workforce in Hungary by 2,000 to 22,500, as it expands its network to comprise 78 stores and 50 gas stations, state news service MTI said Wednesday.   Tesco opened its 72nd supermarket in Hungary Wednesday. This latest store, in the southeast of the country, employs 150 people and includes a gas station.   -By Edith Balazs, Dow Jones Newswires; +361-267-0623; edith.balazs@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 07:04 ET (11:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Alaska Air Group Reports June Traffic
Story: SEATTLE, July 4 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Alaska Air Group, Inc. (NYSE: ALK) today reported June passenger traffic for its subsidiaries, Alaska Airlines (Alaska) and Horizon Air (Horizon).        ALASKA AIRLINES     Alaska's June traffic increased 4.9 percent to 1.723 billion revenue passenger miles (RPMs) from 1.642 billion flown a year earlier. Capacity during June was 2.119 billion available seat miles (ASMs), 5.2 percent higher than the 2.014 billion in June 2006.     The passenger load factor (the percentage of available seats occupied by fare-paying passengers) for the month was 81.3 percent, compared to 81.5 percent in June 2006. The airline carried 1,645,900 passengers, compared to 1,579,100 in June 2006.     RPMs for the six-month period totaled 8.886 billion, a 2.1 percent increase from the 8.706 billion recorded a year earlier. Capacity for the six months ended June 2007 increased 4.1 percent to 11.834 billion ASMs, compared to 11.373 billion in 2006.     The passenger load factor for the first six months of 2007 was 75.1 percent, compared to 76.5 percent in 2006. The airline carried 8,489,400 passengers, compared to 8,348,100 in 2006.        HORIZON AIR     Horizon's June traffic increased 8.0 percent to 258.2 million RPMs from 239.0 million flown a year earlier. Capacity during June was 325.9 million ASMs, 8.0 percent higher than the 301.8 million in June 2006.     The passenger load factor for the month was 79.2 percent, matching the 79.2 percent in June 2006. The airline carried 674,700 passengers, compared to 608,200 in June 2006.     RPMs for the six-month period totaled 1.356 billion, a 3.5 percent increase from the 1.310 billion recorded a year earlier. Capacity during the six months ended June 2007 increased 6.7 percent to 1.898 billion ASMs, compared to 1.778 billion in 2006.     The passenger load factor for the first six months of 2007 was 71.4 percent, compared to 73.7 percent in 2006. The airline carried 3,517,800 passengers, compared to 3,339,200 in 2006.     For Horizon's network flying (which excludes those flights operated as Frontier JetExpress), June traffic increased 22.5 percent to 223.7 million RPMs from 182.6 million flown a year earlier. Capacity during June was 278.5 million ASMs, 20.1 percent higher than the 231.8 million in June 2006.     The passenger load factor for the month was a record 80.3 percent, compared to 78.8 percent in June 2006. The airline carried 610,000 passengers, compared to 516,200 in June 2006.     RPMs for the six-month period totaled 1.149 billion, a 15.6 percent increase from the 994.3 million recorded a year earlier. Capacity during the six months ended June 2007 increased 17.0 percent to 1.586 billion ASMs, compared to 1.356 billion in 2006.     The passenger load factor for the first six months of 2007 was 72.4 percent, compared to 73.4 percent in 2006. The airline carried 3,179,000 passengers, compared to 2,859,000 in 2006.     Horizon's RPMs, passenger load factor and passengers are reported using actual June operating data for flights operated as Horizon Air combined with the estimated operating data for Horizon's regional jet service operated as Frontier JetExpress.     Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air together serve 92 cities through an expansive network throughout Alaska, the Lower 48, Canada and Mexico. For reservations visit http://alaskaair.com. For more news and information, visit the Alaska Airlines/Horizon Air Newsroom at http://alaskaair.com/newsroom.    SOURCE  Alaska Air Group, Inc.       /CONTACT: media contact, Amanda Tobin Bielawski, Media Relations Manager, +1-206-392-5134, or investor-analyst contact, Shannon Alberts, Managing Director of Investor Relations, +1-206-392-5218, both of Alaska Air Group, Inc.      /Web site: http://www.alaskaair.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 08:00 ET (12:00 GMT)

Headline: : Scotiabank Appoints New Executive Vice-President For Domestic Personal Lending & Insurance>BNS.T
Story: TORONTO, July 4 /CNW/ - Scotiabank today announced that Robin Hibberd has been appointed Executive Vice-President, Domestic Personal Lending & Insurance, and President and CEO, Scotia Mortgage Corporation. Mr. Hibberd is responsible for the Domestic business units that comprise consumer lending, including mortgages, credit cards, personal loans and insurance, as well as credit risk management and integrated business solutions. He begins his new position on July 4, 2007, reporting to Chris Hodgson, Executive Vice-President and Head of Domestic Personal Banking.    A 20-year Scotiabank veteran, Mr. Hibberd is currently serving as Senior Vice-President, Corporate Development. Prior to that, he was Senior Vice-President, Asia Pacific, based in Hong Kong. Mr. Hibberd's overseas service built upon six years experience in positions of increasing responsibility in Domestic Personal Banking. He replaces Jane Rowe, who is taking a one-year leave of absence and it is anticipated that she will return to a new role next year.    "Robin has demonstrated tremendous leadership qualities during his career at Scotiabank - both overseas and with the Domestic Bank," Mr. Hodgson said. "I also want to wish Jane well during her leave of absence and thank her for her contribution to the Domestic Personal Banking team."    Mr. Hibberd is a Chartered Accountant and has a Masters in Business Administration from the Richard Ivey School of Business, University of Western Ontario.    Scotiabank is one of North America's premier financial institutions and Canada's most international bank. With more than 58,000 employees, Scotiabank Group and its affiliates serve approximately 12 million customers in some 50 countries around the world. Scotiabank offers a diverse range of products and services including personal, commercial, corporate and investment banking. With $412 billion in assets (as at April 30, 2007), Scotiabank trades on the Toronto (BNS) and New York Exchanges (BNS). For more information please visit www.scotiabank.com.             /CONTACT: Ann DeRabbie, Scotiabank, Public Affairs, (416) 933-1344     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 15:00 ET (19:00 GMT)

Headline: 2nd UPDATE: Sportingbet's Bwin Tie-Up Talks Off, Shares Drop
Story: (This updates an article published at 1035 GMT with Bwin and analyst comments, background.)     By Lilly Vitorovich   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--Sportingbet PLC (SBT.LN) said Wednesday that tie-up talks with Bwin Interactive Entertainment AG (BWIN.IV) have been called-off, four months after the U.K.-listed online sports betting and gambling group confirmed it had received a preliminary bid approach.   In a brief two-sentence statement to the London Stock Exchange, Sportingbet said the talks "have now been mutually and amicably discontinued", triggering a sharp share drop.  No further details were provided by the group.   A Sportingbet spokesman told Dow Jones Newswires that talks were constructive but they couldn't find a middle ground. He declined to comment further.   The announcement was expected among some industry observers and gaming analysts following growing uncertainty about the online gambling industry in Europe and Bwin's falling share price in recent months, Daniel Stewart & Co. analyst James Hollins said.   Some investors thought that Bwin's falling share price might have affected any deal involving Bwin securities, he noted.   There has been good institutional support for Sportingbet based on fundamentals of late, with the group doing well operationally, said Hollins, who is reinstating Sportingbet with a buy rating and 62 pence target price.   Daniel Stewart & Co. are house brokers to Sportingbet.   At 1115 GMT, Sportingbet shares were down 5 pence, or 8.9%, to 54 pence, valuing the group at GBP231.6 million, in a slightly higher London market. Bwin shares were steady at EUR24.13 in a flat Vienna market.   Last month, Sportingbet posted a sharp rise in third-quarter group operating profit, and said it remained confident for the remainder of the financial year.   Stripping out exceptional charges, goodwill amortization and share option charges, group operating profit rose more than threefold to GBP3.0 million in the third quarter ended April 30 from GBP0.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The third-quarter result was underpinned by a strong performance in Sportingbet's core sports betting operations.   Group operating profit before exceptional items is the key figure U.K. investors and analyst track when assessing the group's operating performance.   Turnover from continuing operations rose to GBP291.1 million in the third-quarter from GBP229.4 million a year ago.   In order to aid comparison, the financial and operational information for the prior period is stated excluding the U.S. business, which was sold in October 2006, resulting in Sportingbet's exit from the market.    On March 7, Sportingbet confirmed it was in talks with Austria-based Bwin about the possible acquisition of Sportingbet in the wake of recent press speculation.     Company Web site: http://www.sportingbet.com                       http://www.bwin.com     -By Lilly Vitorovich, Dow Jones Newswires; 44-0-207 842 9290; lilly.vitorovich@dowjones.com     (Flemming Hansen in Vienna contributed to this story.)       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 07:20 ET (11:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Brazil Utility Itapebi Issues BRL175M In Debentures
Story: SAO PAULO (Dow Jones)--Brazilian hydroelectric power company Itapebi Geracao de Energia SA completed its non-convertible debenture issue worth 175 million Brazilian reals ($91 million), the company said Wednesday in a statement.   The issue was part of a two-year program totaling BRL250 million.   Banco Votorantim was the lead coordinator of the operation, which was rated at brAA- by Standard & Poor's.   The debentures were issued in two series.   The first series, totaling BRL87.5 million, will mature June 1, 2012, and the company will pay an annual interest rate of 9.5 percentage points over Brazil's General Price Index, known as the IGP-M.   The second series, also worth BRL87.5 million, will mature Dec. 1, 2012. Itapebi also will pay an annual interest rate of 9.5 percentage points over the IGP-M. The debentures were acquired by 28 investors, including 24 investment funds.   Itapebi is controlled by holding company Neoenergia SA (GNAN3B.SM), which is a subsidiary of Spain's Iberdrola (IBE.MC).   The issue comes amid relatively tepid debenture activity in 2007.   So far this year, local companies have raised just BRL4.8 billion from debenture issues. Currently, the the Brazilian Securities Commission, or CVM, is studying requests by companies for the issuance of an additional BRL17 billion in debentures.   In 2006, Brazilian companies issued BRL69.4 billion in debentures, the largest volume ever in the local market. The previous record was set in 2005, when Brazilian companies issued BRL41.54 billion in debentures.     -By Rogerio Jelmayer, Dow Jones Newswires; 5511-3145-1480; rogerio.jelmayer@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 07:43 ET (11:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:Chrysler,China's Chery Auto Sign Pact To Export Cars
Story: By Aaron Back   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     BEIJING (Dow Jones)--DaimlerChrysler AG's (DCX.XE) Chrysler Group and Chinese automaker Chery Automobile Co. signed an agreement Wednesday through which Chery will build cars for export under Chrysler brand names, a new low-cost business model for the U.S. automaker.   Chrysler and Chery signed a letter of intent in December, but there had been uncertainty over the deal since DaimlerChrysler's decision in May to sell 80.1% of Chrysler to private-equity concern Cerberus Capital Management L.P.   For Chery the deal is an opportunity to enter the U.S. and European markets, a longtime ambition for the fast-growing company, using well-established American brand names such as Dodge and Jeep.   Chrysler said it will choose several small-car models now being developed by Chery and help make branding, design and regulatory changes to prepare them for export. In the future, both companies will jointly develop new products based on Chery small-car platforms.   "This is the start of a very long relationship between Chrysler and Chery," Chrysler Chief Executive Tom LaSorda said at a press briefing in Beijing on Wednesday.   "As part of the Chrysler Group's global transformation, we're finding new ways to bring vehicles to market faster, more efficiently, with less costs, and with the same high-quality standards," LaSorda said.   The first car to be produced under the deal will carry Chrysler's Dodge brand and will be available within 12 months, though initially only in markets such as South America and Eastern Europe, Chrysler executives said at a press briefing on Wednesday.   LaSorda told reporters on the sidelines of the briefing that he expects cars made under the deal to be sold in the U.S. by "mid-to-late 2009."   Total production under the deal will reach 50,000 to 100,000 or more cars a year, and could be in the hundreds of thousands, LaSorda said.   Chrysler sold 2.14 million vehicles in 2006, down about 7% from a year earlier.   Chery, which specializes in small cars, sold about 300,000 cars last year and says it expects to sell 393,000 cars in 2007. It already exports cars to many developing countries, and has long sought to enter the U.S. market.   The agreement between Chrysler and Chery has been controversial, as labor leaders argue that the deal will turn Chrysler into a "door opener" for China's auto industry as it seeks inroads in the U.S. and Europe.   General Motors Corp. sued Chery in 2004, saying that a Chery subcompact known as the QQ was a copy of the Chevrolet Spark. The two companies settled the suit in 2005, without disclosing the terms.   LaSorda told reporters that there won't initially be any technology transfers to Chery as cars will be built on Chery's current platforms.   "But when we go to work on joint projects, we'll certainly help them with any issues related to technology or product readiness," LaSorda added.   Asked about recent controversy over the safety of Chinese exports, LaSorda said he has "no concerns at all" about Chery.   Chrysler will work with Chery to ensure cars meet safety and other quality standards, he said.   "I've been through their facilities," LaSorda said, "and I don't see any issues with safety or quality."     -By Aaron Back, Dow Jones Newswires; (8610) 6588-5848; aaron.back@dowjones.com   (Jason Leow of The Wall Street Journal Asia contributed to this story.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 03:01 ET (07:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
