Headline: UK 1Q Housing Equity Withdrawal GBP13.2B Vs GBP13.3B In 4Q
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. households withdrew GBP13.2 billion in equity from their homes through new mortgage loans in the first quarter of 2007, the Bank of England said Wednesday.   That was slightly down from the GBP13.3 billion withdrawn in the fourth quarter of 2006, a figure that was revised lower from GBP14.6 billion.   Housing equity withdrawals peaked in the fourth quarter of 2003, when GBP17.3 billion was withdrawn, and fell significantly in 2005 as the housing market cooled before picking up again as 2006 progressed and the housing market revived.   The figure for the first quarter was above the GBP11.6 billion withdrawn in the first quarter of 2006.   HEW was unchanged from the fourth quarter at 6.1% of post-tax income, but up from 5.4% of post-tax income in the first quarter of 2006.   The data measure the portion of borrowing secured on residential property that isn't invested in the U.K. housing market, but used to finance consumption or invest in financial assets.   Web site: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/   -By Paul Hannon; Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0) 207 842 9491; paul.hannon@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 04:57 ET (08:57 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Bombardier Wins A 53M Euro Order From Transport For London For 36 Additional Electric Multiple Unit Cars For The United Kingdom>BBD.A.T
Story: BERLIN, GERMANY--(CCNMatthews - July 04, 2007) - Bombardier has been awarded an additional order for the provision of 36 ELECTROSTAR(i) electric multiple unit cars, together with an associated Train Services Agreement from Transport for London (TfL) to be operated on the East London Railway and North London Railway. This order is the first tranche of an option provided for within the original contract for 152 ELECTROSTAR cars announced on 31st August 2006.    The contract value is approximately 53 million euros ($72 million US) which includes vehicle manufacture and the first 7.5 years of a Train Services Agreement for the new vehicles which may extend for up to 30 years. The new vehicles will follow on from the production of the 152 cars, commencing in March 2009, with the last vehicle delivered in May 2010.    The 75mph Class 378 units are specially designed for suburban operations and are part of the proven and reliable ELECTROSTAR family of products. 1,614 ELECTROSTAR cars are already in daily passenger service with three UK operators, c2c, Southeastern and Southern Railways.    The new vehicles will be manufactured at Bombardier's production site at Derby and the servicing will be primarily delivered out of a new purpose-built maintenance facility situated at New Cross Gate in East London.    Commenting on this announcement, Colin S Walton, Chief Country Representative UK said: "Our award winning ELECTROSTAR trains are the most reliable new generation EMUs on the UK network and the similar Class 376 suburban vehicles have already proven themselves in the London area. The vehicle supply will be complimented by our excellent services provision, which has proved highly successful with other UK operators, winning a number of awards over the past year. This order will help secure employment for our highly specialized workforce at Derby."    Stephane Rambaud-Measson, President of Bombardier Transportation's Mainline Division, commented: "This important additional order from TfL further demonstrates the benefits and flexibility of the ELECTROSTAR family of trains. The trains' modular design allows us to retain the longevity of the ELECTROSTAR platform for both suburban and intercity applications alike".    In the UK's rail transportation industry, Bombardier is the leader in the manufacture and maintenance of rolling stock. Bombardier Transportation employs over 4,000 people at production facilities in Derby and Plymouth and 24 maintenance, refurbishment and overhaul centres across the UK. The company maintains approximately 2500 vehicles.    Note to editors:    Useful company background facts and contact details follow.    Photography is available at:    http://www.tfl.gov.uk/tfl/corporate/media/photos/pressimages    Background facts and figures    About Bombardier Transportation    Bombardier Transportation has its global headquarters in Berlin, Germany with a presence in over 60 countries. It has an installed base of over 100,000 vehicles worldwide. The Group offers the broadest product portfolio and is recognized as the leader in the global rail sector.    About Bombardier    A world-leading manufacturer of innovative transportation solutions, from regional aircraft and business jets to rail transportation equipment, systems and services, Bombardier Inc. is a global corporation headquartered in Canada. Headline: Dexia Launching New Mortgage Bond Bank In Luxembourg
Story: Edited Press Release     BRUSSELS (Dow Jones)--Franco-Belgian banking group Dexia SA (DEXB.BT) said Tuesday that its new Dexia LdG Banque S.A. unit has obtained authorization from the Luxembourg Treasury and Budget Ministry to conduct all business covered by the law of Nov. 21 1997 relating to mortgage bond issuing banks.   In accordance with this law, Dexia LdG Banque's principal activity will be the refinancing of assets generated by the Dexia group's public sector financing business in OECD countries and in the European Economic Area through the issuance of covered bonds.   By bringing together two existing issuers of triple-A rated covered bonds within Dexia, Dexia Municipal Agency and Dexia Kommunalbank Deutschland, Dexia LdG Banque S.A. will enhance the group's refinancing capacity in a context of major development of its flagship local public sector financing services.   After a second half of 2007 devoted to the issuer's startup operations, Dexia LdG Banque S.A. plans to enter the international markets from the beginning of 2008, with the objective of rapidly positioning itself as a top quality issuer in its market.   Marc Henry, Managing Director and Chairman of the Management Board will lead the new bank together with Jacques Dupuis, currently head of Credit Research in Dexia's Financial Markets division.  Company website: http://www.dexia.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 11:52 ET (15:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 2nd UPDATE: Sodexho 3Q Revs +2.4%; Vouchers Outpace Some Ops
Story: (This updates an item that ran at 0834 GMT with detail and company comments.)       By Mimosa Spencer     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     PARIS (Dow Jones)--French voucher and services company Sodexho (12122.FR) Wednesday reported third-quarter sales were up 2.4%, with its voucher business continuing to grow apace but as a mixed performance in Europe from its services division weighed on growth elsewhere.   In a press statement early Wednesday, Sodexho reported third-quarter sales for the period ending May 31, of EUR3.41 billion compared to EUR3.33 billion a year ago.   Sodexho said the company is confident it will meet its full-year objectives of organic sales growth over 7% and a 12% rise in operating profit growth, excluding any currency impact.   Analysts said the revenue statement was globally in line with their expectations, citing the company's confidence in meeting full-year growth targets.   "The voucher division's growth looks good, it's reassuring that it has maintained its dynamism," said an analyst who declined to be identified.   Sales for the first nine months rose 3.6% to EUR10.22 billion from EUR9.87 billion a year ago.   The strength of the euro compared to the dollar had a 4.2% negative effect on sales for the first nine months, Sodexho executives said on a conference call.   The executives also said inflation affected revenue over the period: "It is clear that in the last few months we've seen some acceleration of food inflation, this is true in U.S. and the U.K., more than in France and continental Europe," said Chief Executive Officer Michel Landel. The company offset the negative impact through productivity gains in food activities and labor costs, Landel added.   Sodexho's core business of food and facilities management services posted 3.2% growth, or 7.4% growth on a like-for-like basis, to EUR9.91 billion as slower growth in Europe dragged on double-digit growth in the region the company calls 'rest of the world' which includes the Middle East, Africa and Latin America.   The strength of the mining sector in Latin America and Australia and high oil prices drove demand for Sodexho services in the Middle East and Africa, company executives said.   The fast-growing vouchers business grew 19% to EUR323 million from EUR273 million a year ago.   Sodexho's vouchers business, which includes gift vouchers and meal tickets, in large part sold to employers who distribute them to employees, was lifted by strong demand in Latin America and Asia.   The performance of the food services and facilities management division operations in Europe were weighed down by the Netherlands and Italy.   Stronger growth for this division came from central Europe, especially Spain.   Sales growth in the U.K. and Ireland was led by contracts in the healthcare sector, the company said.   At 1016 GMT, shares were up 0.7% or EUR0.39 at EUR54.33, against a slightly higher Paris market, giving the company a market capitalization of EUR8.6 billion.     -Company Web site: http://www.sodexho.com     By Mimosa Spencer, Dow Jones Newswires; +33 1 40 17 17 73; mimosa.spencer@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 06:20 ET (10:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Cosmo Pharmaceuticals: Positive Results For CB-01-11
Story: Edited Press Release   LAINATE, Italy (Dow Jones)--Swiss-listed Italian company Cosmo Pharmaceuticals SpA (COPN.EB) Wednesday reported positive preliminary results from its phase II/III study with CB-01-11, or Rifamycin SV MMX, in infectious diarrhoea.   CB-01-11 is a broad spectrum, semi-synthetic antibiotic that is not absorbed when taken in tablet form. Through the use of Cosmo's MMX technology, which delivers the active ingredient into the colon, bacteria in the gastro intestinal tract that are important for vitamin synthesis are not sterilized. Given that it is practically not absorbed CB-01-11 is potentially applicable for the treatment of long term infections in the colon.   In the placebo controlled, randomized, double blind trial 120 patients in 8 sites in South Africa were treated with a 200mg tablet, 4 times per day for 3 days.  The trial assessed non-inferiority versus Normix, rifaximin, and the primary endpoint was the time from first ingestion of tablet to the last unformed stool. According to the preliminary reports CB-01-11 met this primary endpoint.   Mauro Ajani, CEO of Cosmo Pharmaceuticals, commented: "We are very encouraged about these preliminary results since many of the needs of patients are not adequately met with products currently on the market. Infections of the colon affect many more persons than colon inflammations and this is consequently a substantially larger market. We believe that our proprietary MMX technology will enable us to improve a range of products in colon infections and thus better meet patients' requirements."   Company Web Site: http://www.cosmopharmaceuticals.com   -Zurich Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 8040; zurichdjnews@dowjones.com     Corrected July 4, 2007 01:29 ET (05:29 GMT)  (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 01:12 ET (05:12 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gas Assoc Head Hopes Japan Can Buy Gas From Sakhalin 1-Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Japan Gas Association Chairman Akio Nomura told reporters Wednesday that he is holding out hope that natural gas produced at Russia's Sakhalin 1 project will be exported to Japan, The Nikkei reported in its Thursday morning edition.   Earlier, Russia's state-controlled gas company, Gazprom (GZPFY), said that it intends to buy and manage exports for all of the natural gas produced at Sakhalin 1.  U.S. oil giant Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM), Marubeni Corp. (8002.TO) and the Japanese government are among the project's investors.   Exxon Mobil, which leads the endeavor, is said to have envisioned supplying natural gas to China via pipeline.  But Gazprom has indicated that it hopes to export the Sakhalin 1 output as liquefied natural gas by using the LNG loading facility at the Sakhalin 2 project, in which Gazprom holds a majority stake.   Should Gazprom's vision be realized, it would become easier for Japan to secure supplies because it has LNG unloading facilities.   "Exporting as LNG is preferable," said Nomura, who is also chairman of Osaka Gas Co. (9532.TO).     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:15 ET (17:15 GMT)

Headline: MARKET TALK: UBS Doesn't Believe Ladbrokes Will Face LBO
Story: 1400 GMT [Dow Jones] UBS doesn't believe Ladbrokes (LAD.LN) will face a leveraged buy out in the wake of recent speculation. "We believe that an LBO bid for Ladbrokes is unlikely (10% probability) as our analysis results in materially unattractive IRRs (Internal Rate of Returns)", broker says. UBS comes to this conclusion despite assuming an exit multiple range of 12.0-13.0x (currently trading at 12.3x), a relatively low 20% premium (bid price 531.6p), historical rates for sales growth and margins and 60/40 debt/equity financing. Ladbrokes +0.1% at 440p. Headline: Brazil Pwr Utility CPFL Mulls Coal-Fired Plant Options-Estado
Story: SAO PAULO (Dow Jones)--Brazilian electric utility CPFL Energia (CPL) is evaluating investments in coal-fired thermoelectric power plants in the south of the country, CPFL Chief Executive Wilson Ferreira said Wednesday, according to the local Estado newswire.   The company's strategy would be to exploit coal deposits in the south of Brazil, he told investors at a meeting in Rio de Janeiro.   "The investment will depend on the opportunities that arise," said Ferreira.   He said coal could become an increasingly important source for energy generation due to the difficulty the government is encountering in obtaining environmental licenses for new hydroelectric projects and the scarcity of natural gas after Bolivia nationalized production there last year. Bolivia is Brazil's main supplier of natural gas.   According to Ferreira, investments in natural gas-fired projects will only be viable in five years after new reserves have been developed in the Santos basin off the southeast coast and if new finds are made in the Espirito Santo basin.   CPFL Energia is a holding company for three main business lines: CPFL Paulista, which manages regulated distribution assets, CPFL Geracao, which manages power plants, and the commercialization unit, CPFL Brasil, which sells power to the unregulated market of large-scale customers. The firms mainly operate in the north of Sao Paulo and Rio Grande do Sul states.     -By Alastair Stewart, Dow Jones Newswires; 5511 3145-1479; alastair.stewart@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 16:26 ET (20:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Vaaldiam Announces Intention To -2-
Story: Brent Jellicoe, Great Western's President and CEO, said today: "The proposed bid from Vaaldiam creates a vertically integrated production and exploration company poised to capitalize on a wealth of diamond projects, in-house technical expertise, and management experience. The combined corporate entity has the size and strength to fund high-potential projects in both Brazil and Canada resulting in significant value added to shareholders from year-round field operations that substantially reduce risk in all facets of our exploration profile. For these reasons, the proposed bid presents a substantial opportunity for Great Western shareholders to participate in building a strong new diamond exploration and development company." Headline: Forex Focus: Euro Will Push Ahead Despite Intervention Talk
Story: By Nicholas Hastings   A DOW JONES NEWSWIRES COLUMN     LONDON (Dow Jones)--Talk of intervention, hypothetical or not, is hardly going to hold the euro back, even though the single currency is at or near historical highs against the yen and the dollar.   First, hawkish monetary policy conditions suggest that any attempts to push the euro lower wouldn't work.   And second, economic conditions, including strong euro-zone exports, suggest that a weaker euro is hardly warranted.   As such, market sources remain convinced that the single currency will continue pushing higher with technical analysts at Barclays Capital in London forecasting that once the euro breaks through resistance at $1.3685, it will head for $1.4000 or $1.4100.   The ability of the euro to extend its gains came under the spotlight Tuesday when European Central Bank executive council member Lorenzo Bini Smaghi peppered a speech in Rome with references to intervention.   His comments were seen more as a response to criticism by both Italians and French officials over the recent strength of the euro rather than any serious threat of action.   Late Monday, French President Nicolas Sarkozy repeated recent warnings that the euro is overvalued and inflicting damage on euro-zone industry.   "I want to raise the issue of the euro being overvalued," Sarkozy said.   In his speech, Bini Smaghi acknowledged that intervention can work as it did in 2000, when the ECB helped to boost the value of the euro.   Then, the ECB official pointed out, the success of the exercise was based on its coordination with the U.S. and Japan and on the fact that the effort to push the euro higher was consistent with domestic monetary policy at the time - that is, interest rates were on their way up.   However, this contrasts with current conditions.   There appears to be little reason whey the U.S. and Japan would be interested in coordination at this stage. A weaker dollar and a weaker yen are both seen benefiting the U.S. and Japanese economies at a time when both aren't quite as robust as many have hoped.   And, as far as  domestic euro-zone policy is concerned, interest rates are pointed in the wrong direction.   As the latest purchasing managers' index for manufacturing industry showed Monday and the index for services industry is expected to show Wednesday, the euro-zone economy is going from strength to strength.   The manufacturing PMI rose to 55.6 last month instead of staying unchanged at 55.0 as expected. The index for services is forecast to stay at 58.3.   "This will mark the fourth year of expansion in the services sector and the second year of expansion in the manufacturing sector," noted Mitul Kotecha, chief currency strategist with Calyon in London.   Other analysts are particularly impressed by the improvement in the labor market. "The really encouraging news was that the employment index increased to 53.7 - the highest level since October 2000," noted Martin van Vliet, a senior euro-zone economist with ING Wholesale Banking in Amsterdam.   As a result, the ECB is widely expected to hike rates this September and possibly again before the end of the year - taking them up as high as 4.50% from 4.00% now.   This would certainly ensure that any attempts to push the currency lower would prove futile, especially in a market that continues to be driven largely by yield differentials.   But perhaps intervention talk at this stage looks even more irrelevant when taken in the context of the continued strength of euro-zone exports.   "The ongoing health of the (export-oriented) manufacturing sector in the face of headwinds such as the stronger euro is a confirmation of the euro-zone's economic upturn," noted ING's van Vliet.   "Despite the increase in official rhetoric about the negative impact of the stronger euro, the export (PMI) component actually strengthened further," said Calyon's Kotecha.   Analysts noted that there should also be little to hamper the euro's advance in terms of positioning. Recent data from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange show that euro long positions were pared back to their lowest level this year during May.   "The market is not long and will likely need to chase any rally this time round," noted the analysts at Barclays Capital.   Early Wednesday in Europe with the U.S. on holiday for Independence Day, the euro was able to extend its recent push higher - rising to $1.3627 by 0706 GMT from $1.3617 late Tuesday in New York, according to EBS.   However, the yen found support from a report that Moody's might lift its A2 rating on Japanese domestic debt. The euro was trading hardly changed at Y166.75 from Y166.70.   The dollar slipped back to Y122.38 from Y122.42 even though U.S. Treasury yields settled well over 5.0%, dispelling recent fears that they were about to fall below that level.     Bloomberg TNI FRX POV     Reuters   USD/DJ     Thomson   P/1066 or P/1074     (Nick Hastings has covered the foreign exchange markets and industry for over 15 years. Apart from his written commentary and analysis, he also appears on CNBC television in Europe, Asia and the U.S. He can be contacted on +44-20-7842-9493 or by email: nick.hastings@dowjones.com)  -0-   (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 03:15 ET (07:15 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Italy Govt Mulls Options If Alitalia Auction Fails - Reports
Story: ROME (Dow Jones)--The Italian government could put Alitalia SpA (AZA.MI) into liquidation or re-open discussions with potential buyers like Air France-KLM (AKH) if the auction to sell the airline fails, financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported Wednesday, citing sources close to the government.   The paper reported that Prime Minister Romano Prodi could decide to nominate a liquidator, or a commission to implement an emergency restructuring plan for insolvent companies.   The government is worried about the overall outcome of the race, reported another newspaper, Turin daily La Stampa.   The paper also said that bidder AP Holding SpA, the parent company of Italian carrier Air One, may still lack sufficient funds to buy Alitalia.   Air One, seen as the front-runner in the race, has until now secured the financial backing of Italy's largest retail bank, Intesa Sanpaolo SpA (ISP.MI). Other banks have in recent weeks been looking into backing the bid, but none has taken a final decision.   The other remaining bidder in the race for Alitalia, for which binding offers are due July 12, is U.S. asset company Matlin Patterson.     Newspaper Web sites:  http://www.ilsole24ore.com                           http://www.lastampa.it     -Rome Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 06 678 2543     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 04:00 ET (08:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Private Equity Loans Grow More Than Syndicated Loans-Dealogic
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The volume of global private equity loan financing grew at a much faster year-on-year rate than global syndicated lending in the first half of this year, data provider Dealogic said Wednesday.   Global private equity-backed loan volume climbed to $512 billion, a 68% increase on the first half of last year, it said. Meanwhile, global syndicated lending totaled $2.35 trillion in the first half of this year, a 19% increase over the first six months of 2006.   Dealogic said global subordinated loan pricing continued its downward trend, with average margins falling to 614 basis points, a drop of 75 basis points from the first half of last year.   U.S. firm Blackstone (BX) came top of the sponsor loan table having raised $32.9 billion in the first six months of 2007, Dealogic said.   The volume of private equity-backed loans in Europe, Middle East, and Africa reached the highest first half volume ever, rising 50% on the year to $187.8 billion, it said.   Mezzanine and second lien loans constituted 11% of the EMEA market with second lien volume amounting to $11.1 billion, up from $4 billion in the fist half of 2006.   Staple financing, where banks offer a leverage financing package to private equity firms competing in a leverage buyout, increased to $147.1 billion globally in the first half from $113.4 billion in the corresponding period last year.   European loan volume in the first half of the year increased 21% on the year to $812.1 billion, with Russian lending increasing 174% on the year to $54.2 billion.   Dealogic said Italian borrowers outperformed their European peers with an increase of 232% to $76.3 billion, mainly driven by power company Enel SpA's (EN) $46.8 billion loan to finance the acquisitions of Spain's Endesa (ELE) and Acciona (ANA.MC).   Corporate acquisition loans accounted for 33% of the total EMEA market while refinancing loans accounted for 18%.     -By Michael Wilson, Dow Jones Newswires; 44 20 7842 9349, michael.wilson@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 12:59 ET (16:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Canada Morning: C$ Up Slightly In Holiday-Thinned Trading
Story: TORONTO (Dow Jones)--The Canadian dollar is slightly higher in light, narrow trading early Wednesday, with the close of U.S. financial markets for Independence Day expected to keep a lid on activity.   The U.S. dollar was trading at C$1.0591at 9:25 a.m. EDT (1325 GMT), from C$1.0580 at 8:00 a.m. EDT (1200 GMT), and from C$1.0612 late Tuesday.   Moves for the Canadian dollar in Wednesday's lightly-traded holiday environment have been largely technical in nature, as the currency overnight once again attempted a run at technical barriers in the C$1.0550 region, only to reverse on insufficient momentum.   The currency since has dipped as far as C$1.0615, and a slightly wider range between about C$1.0550 and C$1.0650 is expected to contain it until market liquidity revives on Thursday.   Even then, Canadian dollar activity could remain constrained a bit as market players await Friday's release of the Canadian and U.S. June employment reports, the last major data releases prior to the Bank of Canada's next interest-rate announcement on Tuesday.   Expectations of higher Canadian interest rates beginning Tuesday are seen continuing to underpin the Canadian dollar for the time being, along with strong oil and other commodity prices   Recent corporate merger-and-acquisition activity has also had a role in generating demand for Canadian dollars, and these factors together should help limit the downside for the currency.   "The prospect of the Canadian dollar losing much ground seems limited at present," said chief currency strategist Shaun Osborne of TD Securities in Toronto. "Oil prices are looking comfortable above $70 per barrel, and the M&A news continues to provide good background support for the currency."   These are the exchange rates at 9:25 a.m. EDT (1325 GMT), 8:00 a.m. EDT (1200 GMT), and late Tuesday.   USD/CAD 1.0591 1.0580 1.0612   EUR/CAD 1.4420 1.4412 1.4440   CAD/JPY 115.74 115.72 115.39   -By Paul Evans; Dow Jones Newswires; 416-306-2022; paulr.evans@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 09:29 ET (13:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: MARKET TALK: Fideuram Wargny Lifts Danone Target Price
Story: 0654 GMT [Dow Jones] Fideuram Wargny raises Danone (12062.FR) price target to EUR76 from EUR66 as the brokerage expects Danone to use the EUR4B net gain from the sale of its biscuit division to Kraft Foods (KFT) for "an external growth operation." Thinks a bid on Numico (37561.AE) is possible thanks to synergies in the two groups' baby food activities. Keeps buy rating. Shares closed Tuesday at EUR61.71. Headline: Kraft To Look To Euro Market To Finance Danone Biscuits Buy
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.S.-based Kraft Foods Inc. (KFT), the world's largest cookie maker, is expected to raise debt in the European market to fund its acquisition of the global biscuit division of France's Groupe Danone.   The French food company announced Tuesday that it has entered exclusive talks to sell its biscuit division to Kraft in a transaction valued at EUR5.3 billion ($7.2 billion). This move will allow Kraft expand its presence in Europe and leave Danone to concentrate on its two core businesses of dairy products and mineral water.   "Our intent is to match the borrowing on this with the cash flow so that we get the natural hedges associated with this business. And on that basis, we're looking to more of a euro-based activity," said Jim Dollive, chief financial officer of Kraft Foods said.   Dollive later confirmed again Kraft's intention to issue debt mainly in euros in the Euromarket. However, he stressed that the dynamics of how the company will issue the debt and the structure of the transaction are still to be finalized. "We have got some time to put all that in place," Dollive said.   Moody's Investors Service Tuesday placed the Baa1 senior unsecured ratings of Kraft Foods Inc. and subsidiaries under review for possible downgrade following the announcement that it has bid to acquire the global biscuit business of Danone, and that it would fund the purchase primarily with debt. However, Moody's said that any downgrade is likely to leave Kraft with an investment grade rating.   Standard & Poor's also said it had revised its outlook on Kraft to negative from stable, while Fitch Ratings cut its rating on Kraft to three levels above speculative grade at BBB+ from A-. The agency also downgraded Kraft's senior unsecured debt and the company's existing credit facility to BBB+ from A- and placed the company on watch for another downgrade. S&P rates Kraft's senior unsecured debt at A-.     -By Kate Haywood, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0) 7842 9315; kathryn.haywood@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 05:32 ET (09:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: ITV Audience Share Decline Slows In First Half
Story: By Jessica Hodgson   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--ITV PLC (ITV.LN) Wednesday said the performance of its flagship ITV1 channel was "beginning to stabilize" with the channel's decline in audience share slowing.   ITV1's share of the total available commercial audience fell 5.6% in the six months ended June 20, ITV said, compared with a 9.1% decline in the same period in 2006. ITV1's advertising revenue declined on an overall basis by 9%, the company said, with overall advertising revenue down 5%.   The U.K.'s largest commercial terrestrial broadcaster by sales said the U.K.'s overall television advertising market had declined by 0.3% in the first six months of 2007 and was up 10% in July compared with July 2006, fueled by strong growth in telecoms and pharmaceutical advertising, up 7% and 11% respectively although retail, ITV's largest advertising category, was down by 4%.   ITV1's share of the total adult commercial audience in the first half of 2007 fell 4.7%, the company said, and was down 2.5% in multichannel television homes.   The company also warned that the U.K. cinema advertising market had continued to perform "poorly" and its Carlton Screen Advertising unit was expected to post a full year trading loss, "adversely affected by falling revenues and onerous contractual commitments."   Revenue generated by Friends Reunited, the Internet company ITV acquired in 2005, was up by 25% compared with the same period in 2006, ITV said, without giving a revenue figure.Revenues from ITV Play, the company's interactive gaming channel, will be down by around 67% to GBP9 million in the first half. ITV Play earlier this year lost its designated channel slot shortly after the company suspended all interactive and premium rate services.   The company had earlier found it had incorrectly charged some viewers for using some premium rate services.   Societe Generale analyst Anthony de Larrinaga said the trading statement was broadly in line with market forecasts, although July trading was slightly ahead of expectations. Societe Generale rates ITV hold.   At 0910 GMT shares were trading up 0.1% at 115 pence in London.   Company Web site: http://www.itv.com   -By Jessica Hodgson, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 207 842 92 93; jessica.hodgson@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 05:21 ET (09:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: IBM, Infosys, TCS Not To Bid For Citigroup India Unit-Report
Story: NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--International Business Machines Corp. (IBM), India's Infosys Technologies Ltd. (532540.BY) and Tata Consultancy Services Ltd. (532540.BY) have pulled out of the race to buy an Indian unit of Citigroup Inc. (C) because of expensive valuations, The Times of India reported, without citing any sources.   Private equity firm Blackstone Group (BGP.XX) has also decided not to bid for Citigroup's Indian business process outsourcing arm Citigroup Global Services Ltd., which was recently put on the block and is likely to be valued around $1.2 billion, the report said.   Those now left in the fray include Indian BPO company Genpact and a couple of private equity players, the report said.       Newspaper Web Site: http://www.timesofindia.com     -By New Delhi Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-11-2307 4020; djn.in@dowjones.com   -Edited by Alpana Sarma     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Spain Energy Regulator OKs Acciona-Enel Bid For Endesa-Source
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--The board of Spain's energy regulator CNE approved late Tuesday the joint bid launched by Enel SpA (EN) and Acciona SA (ANA.MC) on Endesa SA (ELE), but plans to impose several conditions on the deal, a person familiar with the approval said Wednesday.   The CNE board voted in favor of approving the deal by a narrow majority of five votes to four, with all four votes against coming from members appointed by the conservative Popular Party, Spain's main opposition party, this person said.   The CNE will now discuss the conditions, and may unveil those at any point during the next few days, this person added.   Acciona, a Spanish infrastructure and energy company, and Enel, an Italian power utility, are the top shareholders of Endesa, Spain's largest power utility by market share, with a combined 46% stake.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 05:41 ET (09:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Superior Plus Income Fund Annouces Appointment Of Kay Best, FCA To Board Of Directors>SPF.DB.A.T
Story: CALGARY, July 4 /CNW/ - Superior Plus Income Fund (the "Fund") today announced the appointment of Kay Best to the board of directors of Superior Plus Administration Inc., the administrator of the Fund, and Superior Plus Inc., general partner of Superior Plus LP., effective July 1, 2007. Ms. Best will be the ninth independent director of the ten member boards and will serve on the audit committee.    "We are very pleased to have Ms. Best join our boards," said Grant Billing, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Superior Plus. "Her appointment to the boards will be a valued addition in ensuring the alignment and support of Superior Plus' value-based growth strategy. The skills and extensive experience of Ms. Best in risk management, finance and strategic business development are complementary to those of the current members of the Board and will be of great value as we continue to focus on stability of distributions and long-term growth."    Ms. Best currently serves as Executive Vice-President, Risk Management and Chief Financial Officer of the Calgary Health Region. Prior thereto, Ms. Best was employed as a Partner with Ernst & Young LLP. Ms. Best is currently a director of Canadian Natural Resources Limited and Enbridge Income Fund.    About Superior Plus and the Fund    =-------------------------------    Superior Plus Income Fund is a diversified business trust. The Fund holds 100% of Superior Plus LP, a limited partnership formed between Superior Plus Inc., as general partner and the Fund as limited partner. Superior Plus is focused on stability of distributions with value growth and has four Canadian based operating divisions: Superior Propane is Canada's largest distributor of propane, related products and services; ERCO Worldwide is a leading supplier of chemicals and technology to the pulp and paper industries and a regional Midwest supplier of chloralkali and potassium products; Winroc is the seventh largest distributor of walls and ceilings construction products in North America; and Superior Energy Management provides fixed price natural gas and electricity supply services in Ontario and natural gas supply in British Columbia and Quebec. Headline: Nikko Cordial Considering Monex Beans Stock Sale - Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Securities house Nikko Cordial Corp. (8603.TO) is considering selling shares in brokerage Monex Beans Holdings Inc. (8698.TO) because of overlapping Internet operations, The Nikkei reported in its Thursday morning edition.   Nikko Cordial is the online brokerage's top shareholder with a 26.3% interest. The stake is worth about Y60 billion based on Wednesday's closing price.   "We would like to make a decision after evaluating the prospects for the online brokerage business," says a Nikko Cordial executive.   Sources close to Monex Beans say that not having a dominant shareholder may benefit the firm. The online brokerage appears to believe that it can broaden client relationships if Nikko Cordial leaves.   Monex Beans was created in 2004 by the merger of Nikko Beans Inc. and Monex Inc. The merged entity has expanded its customer base, offering low fees for investment trusts and other products sold online.   But Monex Beans and other online brokerages are at a crossroads. Their margins have eroded as new firms entered the market, driving down commissions. In addition, start-up stock markets are slumping with individuals wary of risk.   The question is who will take over Nikko's stake in Monex Beans at a time of reorganization for online brokerages. If the stake is sold to a financial institution, the pace of the industry's realignment would accelerate. Mizuho Securities Co. owns a 3% stake in Monex Beans.   Last month, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc. (8306.TO) effectively added kabu.com Securities Co. (8703.TO) to its group. It is also negotiating to take a stake of more than 15% in Matsui Securities Co. (8628.TO), a pioneer in Internet stock trading.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 15:55 ET (19:55 GMT)

Headline: : CanWest MediaWorks Income Fund Unitholders Vote In Favour Of Special Resolution Approving Privatization>CWM.UN.T
Story: TORONTO, July 4 /CNW/ - CanWest Global Communications Corp. and CanWest MediaWorks Income Fund (the "Fund") announced today that the Fund's unitholders voted in favour of the special resolution approving the privatization of the Fund. At a special meeting of the Fund's unitholders held on July 4, 2007, the privatization was approved by 99.06% of the votes cast by the Fund's unitholders of record on May 31, 2007 in accordance with the Fund's declaration of trust and by 99.05% of the votes cast by the Fund's unitholders (other than CanWest Global Communications Corp. and its related parties) in accordance with applicable securities laws.    Completion of the privatization remains subject to the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions specified in the privatization agreement dated May 25, 2007 between CanWest MediaWorks Inc., CWMW Trust, CanWest MediaWorks (Canada) Inc., CanWest MediaWorks Limited Partnership, and the Fund. The Fund anticipates that the privatization will be completed on or about July 10, 2007 and that all of the Fund's units will be redeemed on or about July 12, 2007.    As previously announced on June 19, 2007, the Fund's Board of Trustees has approved a cash distribution of $0.0771 per unit for the month of June 2007 to unitholders of record as of the close of business on June 29, 2007. This distribution will be paid on July 12, 2007 if all of the conditions to completion of the privatization of the Fund are satisfied or waived and the privatization is implemented as currently anticipated. If the privatization is not completed by July 12, 2007, then the distribution will be paid on July 13, 2007.    Forward Looking Statements    =-------------------------    This news release contains certain comments or "forward-looking statements" relating to the privatization of the Fund, including statements regarding the terms and conditions of the proposed transaction and the currently expected closing and redemption dates that are based largely upon current expectations and are subject to certain risks, trends and uncertainties. Statements that are not historical facts are forward-looking and are subject to important risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Factors that could cause actual events to vary from current expectations include, the risks that parties will not proceed with a transaction and that the transaction will not be successfully completed for any reason (including the failure to obtain the required financing). CanWest Global Communications Corp. and the Fund disclaim any intention or obligation to update any forward-looking statement even if new information becomes available as a result of future events or for any other reason.    About CanWest MediaWorks Income Fund and CanWest Global Communications    Corp.    CanWest MediaWorks Income Fund (TSX: CWM.UN; www.cwmincomefund.com) is an unincorporated, open-ended trust that holds an approximate 26% equity interest in CanWest MediaWorks Limited Partnership, which is the largest publisher of newspapers in Canada, as measured by paid circulation, readership and revenue. CanWest MediaWorks Limited Partnership is 74% owned by CanWest MediaWorks Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of CanWest Global Communications Corp. (www.canwestglobal.com), an international media company listed on the TSX (trading symbols: CGS and CGS.A), and Canada's largest media company. CanWest is Canada's largest publisher of daily newspapers, and owns, operates and/or holds substantial interests in free-to-air and subscription-based television networks, out-of-home advertising, web sites, and radio stations and networks in Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Singapore, Indonesia, Turkey, the United States and the United Kingdom.             /CONTACT: Doug Lamb, Executive Vice President and CFO, CanWest MediaWorks Limited Partnership, (416) 383-2325, dlamb@canwest.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 11:33 ET (15:33 GMT)

Headline: Portugal Galp Signs Biofuels Pact With Brazil Petrobras -2-
Story: The agreement covers "the production, marketing and distribution of biodiesel in the Portuguese and European markets" by a new jointly-owned company, Galp said in a statement.   Half of the joint venture's production, 300,000 tons of vegetable oils annually, will be channeled into the production of second-generation biodiesel at Galp Energia's own refineries in Portugal.   The other 300,000 tonnes will be allocated to biodiesel production elsewhere for export to Portugal and other European countries.   The joint venture will therefore help Portugal meet its target of having biofuels account for 10% of total transportation fuels used nationwide by 2010.   The two companies, when they signed a memorandum of understanding in May, said production would start in 2010.   Brazil is one of the world's leading biofuel producers, principally of cane-based ethanol.   -By Filipa Cunha, Dow Jones Newswires; +351-21-3191863; filipa.cunha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 12:08 ET (16:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Brazil CVM Delays Ruling Involving CVRD Fincl Chief -Estado
Story: SAO PAULO (Dow Jones)--The Brazilian Securities Commission, or CVM, delayed until July 10 its ruling in a case involving the chief financial officer of Brazilian mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (RIO), or CVRD, the Estado news agency reported Wednesday.   In the inquiry, the CVM accused CVRD financial chief Fabio Barbosa of not properly disclosing to regulators the possible sale of the company's stake in steelmaker Usinas Siderurgicas de Minas Gerais (USIM5.BR), or Usiminas, and two loans obtained in concert with CVRD-controlled miner Caemi, the report said.   According to the report, the CVM official in charge of the inquiry has proposed a fine of 100,000 Brazilian reals ($52,356) for Barbosa, for not properly disclosing CVRD's intention to sell its stake in Usiminas.   However, the official suggested that the CVM dismiss accusations of non-disclosure of the loans with Caemi.     -By Jeff Fick, Dow Jones Newswires; 55-11-3145-1481; Jeff.Fick@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 16:19 ET (20:19 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: THE SKEPTIC: C&W Incentive Plan Rough At The Edges
Story: By Arindam Nag   A DOW JONES NEWSWIRES COLUMN     LONDON (Dow Jones)--The long-term incentive plan put in place by Cable & Wireless for its senior management is carefully crafted, and all the better for correlating bonuses closely with shareholder returns.   But it is rough at the edges.   The long-term cash incentive plan kicks in from 2009 and will be earned if C&W's businesses - both U.K. and international - can demonstrate that the value of the businesses have increased over its cost of capital.   The executive bonus pool will be equivalent to 10% of the extra value created.   This plan almost tracks the economic value-added method of measuring economic profit of an enterprise, made popular by Stern Stewart & Co., the consulting firm.   The difference is that the EVA method uses net operating profit after taxes while C&W will use the average of a group of sell-side analysts' sum-of-the-parts valuations of the company.   Here's where the concerns creep in. Sell-side analysts, as history have shown, aren't necessarily that accurate in estimating a company's fair value, whether they use SOTP or another method. They're notoriously susceptible to influence from management's own earnings guidance.   SOTP has its weaknesses in that the references for valuing many European companies sometimes come from the U.S. where capital requirements, long-term growth potential, competitive and regulatory environments can be significantly different, undermining the value of the comparison.   And few sell-side analysts are quick to turn bearish when industry fundamentals deteriorate - there's an innate bullishness to the profession.   And by using a consensus estimate, C&W management risk benefiting - or missing out - on minority contrarian assessments of the company that turn out to be on the mark.   Another problem with C&W's LTCIP is that its payable in cash, which cuts across the goal of ensuring the executives are motivated by sustainable shareholder value creation.   An all-cash reward makes it hard to argue that the current cap of GBP20 million on individual executives' bonuses should be scrapped.   It would be better if a significant portion of this incentive plan, if not all of it, were paid in shares, stock options, or stock appreciation rights, with a lock-in period. That's how scores of U.S. companies today compensate senior management.   Dividend payouts and stock appreciation - to which the plan is linked - aren't always an indicator of smart management.  After all, that's also about how well positioned the company is to capture future growth - important for investors in C&W which operates in as competitive and fast-changing industry as telecommunications.   That said, Chairman Richard Lapthorne's new incentive plan - an unchanged salary of GBP386,000 but a new award of 5.5 million shares if the company makes the FTSE Global Telecoms Sector - is better for being tied to future C&W performance.   For a company whose shares used to trade at GBP15 in 2000, but now change hands at GBP2 - albeit twice the level of a year ago -  an improved management incentive program to boost value is welcome. But a stock plan would have been more shareholder friendly than a pure cash plan.     (Arindam Nag has covered business and finance for 16 years in Asia, Europe and the United States. He can be reached at +44 207-842-9289 or by e-mail: arindam.nag@dowjones.com)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 11:37 ET (15:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: INTERVIEW: India Geometric: Modern Buy To Hurt Pft This FY
Story: By Romit Guha     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--India's Geometric Software Solutions Co. Ltd. (532312.BY) expects the acquisition of U.S.-based Modern Engineering, Inc. to hurt its profitability in the current fiscal year ending March 31, 2008, its managing director and chief executive officer said.   "It (the Modern buy) is a drag on profitability. But it adds tremendous value in terms of domain expertise and adding customer base," Ravi Gopinath told Dow Jones Newswires in a recent interview.   Geometric bought a 95% stake in Modern Engineering for $23.75 million in October 2006.   Gopinath said there are "high onsite costs" linked with Modern. "Plus there are training time and costs associated with gradual offshoring of Modern's operations."   Gopinath was referring to most of Modern's operations being handled from its own location in Detroit and Geometric being in the process of shifting some of these operations to its own low-cost sites in India.   He said the aim is to take revenue contribution from Modern's offshore operations to around 16% by the fiscal fourth quarter, from about 3%-5% now.   "We expect the initial positive impact from the third quarter onward," he said.   Gopinath said the mid-sized company, which specializes in engineering software services, doesn't expect to expand operating margins in this fiscal year because of the Modern buy, but is likely to sustain it at 12%.   "Our effort is to see no further dilution in operating margins as compared to what we had last year," Gopinath said.   The company's operating margins in fiscal year ended March 2006 was at 14.4%.   "From next year onwards (starting April 1, 2008), as the offshoring starts to increase in volume, then we start driving margins northwards," he said.   Gopinath didn't give any specific earnings forecast for the current quarter ended June 30, but said: "The Q1 results will on track with the guidance that we gave."   For the current fiscal, the company has forecast its net profit to grow 30%-35% on year and revenue to grow 50%.   The company had posted net profit of INR374.4 million on revenue of INR3.83 billion in the last fiscal year.   Gopinath expects revenue from its global engineering business to be around $125 million-$130 million in three years from around $33.2 million now.   Revenue from global engineering business currently accounts for about 39% of the company's total revenue.     Pricing Under Pressure     Gopinath said Geometric was currently facing a "challenged" pricing scenario in the U.S., its largest market, which contributes 63% to the company's total revenue.   "The onsite rates in the industrial and automotive sector is under pressure because of huge labor supply," said Gopinath.   "But we are only signing deals which are in line with our profitability guideline," he said.   He added that the company isn't seeing pressure in the "higher end activity" and in the product lifecycle management software services space. He didn't elaborate.   The company's offshore rates - at its own offices - ranges from $15 to $30 per person per hour, while onsite rates - at client sites - ranges from the high-$40s to mid-$70s per person per hour, Gopinath said.   Geometric is currently in the running for about 15 "very high potential deals," with sizes varying from "a quarter of a million dollars to $2 million," he said, adding that the sales cycle for the company is about six months.   To offset the effects of volatile pricing, Geometric is looking to improve the ratio of fixed price contracts vis-à-vis dynamic pricing, he said.   "When you are doing a fixed price project, you can execute the contracts at a higher degree of productivity and hence can create bottomline benefits," explained Gopinath.   He said that company's fixed price revenue ratio has already gone up to 15%-16% of total revenue in the latest fourth quarter from 6% a year earlier.   "A year from now, revenue from fixed price contracts should be around 35%-40%," he added.   In order to deal with rising staff and real estate costs, the company is planning to diversify its workforce into different low-cost countries.   It is planning to scale up its staff strength at its engineering centers in China and Europe and is planning to set up such a center in Latin America. He didn't elaborate.   The company currently has about 2,700 employees and is planning to hire 800-1,000 more by the end of the current fiscal year, Gopinath said.     -By Romit Guha, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com   -Edited by Alpana Sarma     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 01:23 ET (05:23 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Carphone Warehouse Eyeing Mkt, Bond Unlikely This Wk-Sources
Story: By Kate Haywood and Jessica Hodgson   Dow Jones Newswires     LONDON (Dow Jones)--Carphone Warehouse (CPW.LN) is unlikely to launch its planned sterling-denominated benchmark bond deal this week and the company is continuing to monitor conditions in the European credit markets with a view to proceeding with the transaction when they improve, people familiar with the situation said Wednesday.   "We've made clear that we will tap the bond market at a time of our choosing. Now is not that time," a spokesperson for the U.K. broadband and mobile phone retailer told Dow Jones Newswires.   Increased volatility in global financial markets has forced a number of companies to defer plans for new bond deals over the last week or so, reinforcing fears that the days of cheap and easy money for borrowers may be over.   Carphone Warehouse originally announced plans for what would be its debut sterling bond offering June 18. Investor roadshows for the issue ended June 26 through lead managers Barclays Capital, HSBC and The Royal Bank Of Scotland. The bond was expected to price after the roadshows finished, subject to market conditions.   One person familiar with the transaction said that while book building for the transaction was now unlikely to take place this week, it could go ahead next week if the market backdrop improves sufficiently.   "If there is a dramatic improvement in the market on Thursday, then this is a transaction which could move pretty quickly. But my feeling is that the European market and European investors want to wait to see where the U.S. market comes in next week before deals start to get priced," the person said.   But if the recent turbulence continues, the deal is likely to come to market in the autumn.   Other corporate borrowers are taking a similar approach. ProLogis International (PLD), the world's largest owner, manager and developer of distribution facilities, is also waiting to see whether market conditions improve before launching its 10-year, euro-denominated, benchmark bond issue through lead managers ABN AMRO and Banc of America Securities, a person familiar with the transaction said.   Conversely, Barry Callebaut (BARN.EB), the Swiss maker of cocoa, chocolate and confectionary, is pushing ahead with its EUR350 million 10-year bond offering. The deal, which is non-callable for life, is set to price later Wednesday at 125 basis points over mid-swaps, the tight end of initial guidance in the 130 basis points area, one of the lead managers said.   Goldman Sachs, ABN AMRO and BNP Paribas are leading the issue.     -By Kate Haywood, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0) 20 7842 9315; kate.haywood@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 10:00 ET (14:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: France's Arkema Plans To Buy Coatex From Switzerland's Omya
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--French chemical company Arkema (1031383.FR) said Tuesday it plans to acquire the Coatex group, a specialty polymers company currently owned by the Omya Group.   "This first acquisition is fully in line with the [group's] external growth strategy ... for its core business," Arkema said in a statement.   Coatex manufactures specialty polymers, mainly acrylic based, used as dispersants and thickeners, Arkema said.   No financial details were provided.   Coatex reported sales of EUR150 million for 2006, Arkema said.   Company Website: www.arkema.com     -By Alice Dore, Dow Jones Newswires; +33 1 4017 1740; alice.dore@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 00:52 ET (04:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Researchers ID Genetic Mutation That May Alter Patients' Response To Cancer Therapeutics: Eli Lily
Story: INDIANAPOLIS, July 4 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Researchers from Eli Lilly & Company and the Phoenix-based Translational Genomics Research Institute (TGen) today announced finding a novel recurring mutation of the gene AKT1 in breast, colorectal and ovarian cancers. The altered form of AKT1 appears to cause tumor cell proliferation and may play a role in making cells resistant to certain types of therapies. The findings are reported in an advance online publication (AOP) of the journal Nature.     The PI3-Kinase/AKT pathway is among the most commonly activated cellular pathways in human cancers and members of this pathway are among the most frequently targeted for new cancer drug discovery efforts. Activation of this pathway results in cancer cell growth and cell survival.  Although AKT1 is central to pathway activation, its role in cancer has been that of an intermediary between mutated upstream regulatory proteins and downstream survival signaling proteins. This is the first evidence of direct mutation of AKT1 in human cancer tumors: it was discovered in clinical samples from cancer patients, yet has never been detected in cancer cell lines.     "This discovery is a seminal finding in cancer biology that confirms AKT1 as an oncogene in breast, colorectal and ovarian cancer.  The mutation alters the electrostatics of binding pocket in the pleckstrin homology domain, the portion of the enzyme that docks with phospholipids on the cell membrane," said Kerry L. Blanchard, PhD, MD, Executive Director, Discovery Biology Research, Eli Lilly & Company.     To identify the AKT1 mutation, the researchers analyzed 150 tumor samples from patients with either breast, colorectal or ovarian cancer (50 samples from each tumor type). Analysis of the data showed that 8 percent of breast, 6 percent of colorectal and 2 percent of ovarian tumors had the AKT1 mutation in the samples that were screened in their study.     "Recently, molecular features such as the AKT1 mutation are beginning to change drug development efforts. This discovery adds to the short but growing list of molecular features that may help guide both current and future cancer drug development," said John Carpten, PhD, Senior Investigator and Director of TGen's Integrated Cancer Genomics Division and the study's lead author. "The next step is to determine the prevalence of the AKT1 mutation in different populations and, hopefully, use the information gained to stratify patients going into clinical trials for AKT inhibitors."     If validated by further studies, the identification of this recurring mutation has the potential to impact cancer treatment and drug development.     "This is a gorgeous study that used a variety of sophisticated techniques to provide new insights into the tumorigenic process," said Bert Vogelstein, MD, Director of the Ludwig Center for Cancer Genetics & Therapeutics at The Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center.     James E. Thomas, PhD, of Lilly's Cancer Discovery Research division, ex- plained, "AKT1 is a protein kinase or enzyme that plays a key role in activating survival, proliferation and metabolic pathways. Interestingly, other cellular proteins that regulate this network have also been shown to be mutated in a variety of cancers including lung, breast ovary, prostate, colorectal and brain cancers. This mutation in AKT1 is striking direct evidence for the role of AKT1 in cancer formation."     The identification of the AKT1 mutation was a collaborative effort between Eli Lilly & Company and TGen. "This discovery demonstrates the importance of studying the genetic make up of cancers at the clinical level rather than re- lying on model systems," adds Jeffrey Trent, PhD, Scientific Director of TGen.     "This is a key study highlighting Lilly's commitment to translational re- search approaches in cancer drug discovery and development. Furthermore, this work is a great example of a successful public-private partnership at a global level that involves Lilly Research Laboratories in Indianapolis, TGen in Phoenix, Lilly Singapore Centre for Drug Discovery, and the Economic Development Board of Singapore," adds Richard Gaynor, MD, Vice President of Oncology Discovery at Eli Lilly & Company. He added, "This mutation further validates AKT1 as an attractive drug target, and it also will be a valuable tool for the stratification of patients for targeted therapies. This paradigm of identifying specific defects in cancer cells to successfully develop innovative therapies has been validated with oncology drugs such as Gleevec in leukemia and Herceptin in breast cancer."        About Lilly     Lilly, a leading innovation-driven corporation, is developing a growing portfolio of first-in-class and best-in-class pharmaceutical products by applying the latest research from its own worldwide laboratories and from collaborations with eminent scientific organizations. Headquartered in Indianapolis, Ind., Lilly provides answers -- through medicines and information - for some of the world's most urgent medical needs.  Additional information about Lilly is available at www.lilly.com.        About TGen     The Translational Genomics Research Institute (TGen), a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization, is focused on developing earlier diagnoses and smarter treatments. Translational genomics research is a relatively new field employ- ing innovative advances arising from the Human Genome Project and applying them to the development of diagnostics, prognostics and therapies for cancer, neurological disorders, diabetes and other complex diseases. TGen's research is based on personalized medicine and the institute plans to accomplish its goals through robust and disease-focused research.        O-LLY        (Logo:  http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20031219/LLYLOGO )    SOURCE  Eli Lilly & Company     /CONTACT: Asia Martin, Communications Manager, Lilly Research Laboratories of Eli Lilly and Company, +1-317-276-6987, asia.martin@lilly.com; or Amy Erickson of Translational Genomics Research Institute (TGen) +1-602-343-8522, aerickson@tgen.org      /Web site: http://www.lilly.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:31 ET (17:31 GMT)

Headline: Entrust Estimates 2Q Rev Of $24.3M >ENTU
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Dallas-based Entrust Inc. (ENTU) expects total revenue for the second quarter to be about $24.3 million, an increase of 10% over a year earlier.   Product revenue for the quarter is expected to be about $8.8 million, an increase of 20% over the year earlier, and services revenue is expected to be about $15.5 million, up 6% from the second quarter of 2006.   The digital identities and information company expects a net loss of 5 cents a share in the second quarter versus a loss of 2 cents a year earlier. Headline: UPDATE: Sodexho 3Q Revs +2.4%; Vouchers Outpace Other Ops
Story: (This updates an item that ran at 0506 GMT, recasts lead, adds detail and analyst comment)       By Mimosa Spencer     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     PARIS (Dow Jones)--French voucher and services company Sodexho (12122.FR) Wednesday reported third-quarter sales were up 2.4%, with its voucher business continuing to grow apace but as a mixed performance in Europe from its services division weighed on growth elsewhere.   In a press statement early Wednesday, Sodexho reported third-quarter sales for the period ending May 31, of EUR3.41 billion compared to EUR3.33 billion a year ago.   Sodexho said the company is confident it will meet its full-year objectives of organic sales growth over 7% and a 12% rise in operating profit growth, excluding currency impact.   Analysts said the revenue statement was globally in line with their expectations, citing the company's confidence in meeting full-year growth targets.   "The voucher division's growth looks good, it's reassuring that it has maintained its dynamism," said an analyst who declined to be identified.   Sales for the first nine months rose 3.6% to EUR10.22 billion from EUR9.87 billion a year ago.   Sodexho's core business of food and facilities management services posted 3.2% growth, or 7.4% growth on a like-for-like basis, to EUR9.91 billion as slower growth in Europe dragged on double-digit growth in the region the company calls 'rest of the world' which includes the Middle East, Africa and Latin America.   The fast-growing vouchers business grew 19% to EUR323 million from EUR273 million a year ago.   The vouchers business performance was lifted by strong demand in Latin America.   The performance of the food services and facilities management division operations in Europe were weighed down by the Netherlands and Italy. Stronger growth for this division came from central Europe, especially Spain.   Sales growth in the U.K. and Ireland was led by contracts in the healthcare sector, the company said.   Sodexho shares closed at EUR53.94 Tuesday.     -Company Web site: http://www.sodexho.com     -By Mimosa Spencer, Dow Jones Newswires; +33 1 40 17 17 73; mimosa.spencer@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 02:34 ET (06:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Sanyo To Invest Y30B On Lithium-Ion Battery Ops
Story: (Adds background.)     TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Sanyo Electric Co. (6764.TO) said Wednesday it will invest about Y30 billion this fiscal year to boost its output of the type of batteries used in laptops and mobile phones.   The planned output hike underscores Sanyo's current focus on its strengths - its battery operations are one of its few profitable businesses and it has a No. 1 share globally. This is crucial for the company, which is under pressure from Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and other investors to quickly turn itself around.   The Osaka-based electronics maker will expand production lines at two of its plants in Japan to raise output of lithium-ion rechargeable batteries to 70 million a month from 60 million this business year ending in March, a company spokesman said.   Sanyo plans to build a new rechargeable battery plant in Japan in fiscal 2008, but it hasn't picked a site for the factory yet, he said.   Despite recalls of its lithium-ion laptop batteries earlier this year, Sanyo is betting the business will power its reform drive.   Lithium-ion batteries are widely used in portable consumer electronics because they are lightweight and hold charge well when not in use. Demand for the batteries has been strong and is expected to increase.   The global market for the round batteries used in laptop computers and some digital cameras is expected to shoot up 10% this year to Y157 billion, after a 16% rise last year, according to Japan market research firm Fuji Kezai Co.   Sanyo is in the midst of a major restructuring that has included job cuts, factory closings and exits from unprofitable businesses. Last year the company received a Y300 billion bailout from Goldman and other investors.   In March, Lenovo Group Ltd., the Chinese computer maker that bought IBM's PC business, said it was recalling 205,000 lithium-ion laptop batteries made by Sanyo because they could overheat after being struck at a certain angle.     -By Kazuhiro Shimamura, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; kazuhiro.shimamura@dowjones.com   (Hiroyuki Kachi contributed to this article.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 05:45 ET (09:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Europe's Hotel Stocks Rise On Hilton Buyout
Story: By Michael Carolan   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--Hotel stocks across Europe were higher Wednesday as investors reacted to news of Blackstone's $26 billion bid for U.S. hotel giant Hilton Hotels Corporation (HLT).   In the sector's largest ever buyout, the board of Hilton Hotels agreed Tuesday to be acquired by Blackstone for $18.5 billion in cash plus the assumption of $7.5 billion in debt.    The deal had an immediate knock-on effect in Europe as positive sentiment returned to the sector and investors began looking for the next takeover target.   In a slightly higher London market, Intercontinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG) shares rose 66 pence, or 5.2%, to 1323 pence, Whitbread PLC (WTB.LN) rose 95 pence, or 5.4%, to 1848 pence, Millennium & Copthorne PLC (MLC.LN) rose 32 pence, or 4.8%, to 684 pence. In Paris, Accor SA (12040.FR) shares were up 7.1% at EUR69.5 while in Madrid, shares of both NH Hoteles S.A. (NHH.MC) and Sol Melia S.A. (SOL.MC) were higher.   Teather & Greenwood's Mark Reed said the Hilton deal wouldn't necessarily increase the likelihood of further deals in the hotel sector, but it would certainly boost confidence.   The price of the Hilton deal represents a premium of 40%over Monday's closing stock price.   Numis Securities' Richard Carter said the sector is at a point in the cycle where deals which seemed unthinkable 12 months ago are now happening apace. Carter expects Whitbread to come under pressure to spin off its Costa Coffee unit and adopt a more innovative property ownership structure.   Bridgewell's Kate Pettem says that the read-across to Whitbread (WTB.LN) is not directly comparable, as most of Hilton's earnings come from franchised operations. Whitbread runs the U.K. budget hotel chain Premier Inn.   "It does give us comfort though, that a hot market for hotel deals has not diminished, and apparently high multiples are still being paid," she said.   One analyst said investor focus would now naturally shift to Intercontinental Hotels.   IHG's strong position in emerging markets - especially China - and its GBP1 billion worth of property assets make it an obvious target for private equity.   Accor SA (12040.FR), meanwhile, has its own private equity interest to deal with. Colony Capital Tuesday said it had raised its stake in the French hotels group to 10.3% after converting EUR500 million in bonds to shares.   Colony Capital invested EUR1 billion in Accor debt in May 2005, comprising EUR500 million in exchangeable bonds and EUR500 million in convertible bonds.   The private equity firm pushed the hotels group to change its management and strategy, shedding non-core assets and restructuring its real-estate portfolio.   Analysts said the stake increase does not change Accor's valuation.   "We believe that Colony, in the recent interest rate environment, is increasing its exposure to equity markets," said Matthias Desmarais, analyst with Societe Generale.     Company Web sites: http://ichotelsgroup.com                      http://www.whitbread.co.uk   -By Michael Carolan, Dow Jones Newswires; 44-20-7842-9278; michael.carolan@dowjones.com   (Mimosa Spencer in Paris contributed to this article.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 04:25 ET (08:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
