Headline: Brazil Accepts Abbott Offer To Cut Price On AIDS Drug Kaletra
Story: RIO DE JANEIRO (Dow Jones)--Brazil's government has accepted an offer by Abbott Laboratories (ABT) to provide the anti-AIDS drug Kaletra at the price of $1,000 per patient a year, the company said Wednesday.   The agreement, signed by Brazil's Health Minister Jose Gomes Temporao, follows the company's announcement on April 10 that it would reduce the price of the drug in 45 low- and low-middle income countries, such as Brazil.   Brazil has repeatedly pressured Abbott and other drugmakers to lower their prices in order to keep afloat Brazil's policy to provide AIDS medications for free to all patients in the country that need them.   Brazil's government manufactures generic versions of several drugs that were in production before the country enacted an intellectual property law in 1997 to join the World Trade Organization.   Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in May had issued a compulsory license to break the patent on an anti-retroviral AIDS drug made by U.S. pharmaceutical giant Merck & Co. (MRK) after the company rejected sharp price reductions demanded by Brazil.   A compulsory license allows a country to manufacture or buy generic versions of patented drugs while paying the patent holder only a small royalty.   It was the first time Brazil overrode a patent of an anti-AIDS drug, after having threatened to do so for many years.   "The signing of this agreement symbolizes what can be achieved when governments and companies negotiate with the interests of patients in mind," Heather Mason, vice president of Latin American and Canada Operations at Abbott, said in a company release Wednesday.   "It makes it easier for the government of Brazil to afford medicine that a growing number of its people will need."   Brazil's Health Ministry estimates that currently 600,000 people live with HIV in Brazil. Kaletra, a protease inhibitor, is one of the most commonly used anti-AIDS drugs in Brazil.   The price reduction of Kaletra will result in savings of about $10 million for the Brazilian government, Abbott said.     -By Bernd Radowitz, Dow Jones Newswires; +5521-2553-7322; bernd.radowitz@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 16:20 ET (20:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Telindus Wins New IT Outsourcing Contract With Eandis
Story: Edited Press Release     BRUSSELS (Dow Jones)--Belgian technology company Telindus, a unit of Belgacom SA (BELG.BT), Wednesday said it has landed a new IT outsourcing contract with Eandis worth EUR55.4 million.   The global contract will run for five years and seven months.    Eandis is an independent electricity and gas distributor operating in 239 municipalities in Flanders and with a workforce of over 3,200.    Outsourcing Solutions are the ultimate IT solution for customers who want to concentrate on their core business and, at the same time, develop their IT department to support these core activities with maximum effectiveness.    Eandis has therefore decided to rely on Telindus's experience and know-how for the future development of its IT department.   This will take the form of a full IT Outsourcing contract with a wide scope: laptops, printers, servers, storage, connectivity, etc. Telindus won the contract by successfully demonstrating that it genuinely is the one-stop service supplier for customers who want to focus on their core activities while being able to rely on ICT to support future business growth.    For Telindus, outsourcing projects represent an opportunity  to climb higher in the value chain and act as a strategic, high value-added ICT partner for customers. Telindus differentiates itself through its "me too offer", placing emphasis on business value, continuous innovation, transparency and shared benefit/risk models. Thanks to our strong relations with our partners, we can offer our customers state-of-the-art technology and the most innovative and straightforward solutions.   Company Web site: http://www.telindus.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 12:51 ET (16:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Amisco Swings To 2Q Profit On Gain; Sales Fall 15.2% >IAC.T
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Amisco Industries Ltd. (IAC.T) swung to a profit in its second quarter, helped by a gain of about C$700,000 on a change in the fair value of financial instruments, specifically forward-exchange contracts.   The L'Islet, Que. maker of composite painted tubular and steel sheet residential furniture earned C$523,493 or 13 Canadian cents a share in its latest quarter, compared with a loss of C$159,442 or 4 Canadian cents a year earlier.   Sales totaled C$7.8 million, down 15.2% from C$9.2 million a year earlier.   The company's gross profit margin rose to 27% in its latest quarter from 20.6% a year earlier due to a more favorable exchange rate and improved productivity.   -Judy McKinnon; 416-306-2100; AskNewswires@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 09:29 ET (13:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : 3M Canada Company Forms Alliance With Alberta-based Cantega Technologies Inc.
Story: LONDON, ON, July 4 /CNW/ - 3M Canada today announced a strategic alliance to market a power system solution manufactured by Edmonton-based Cantega Technologies Inc. The agreement provides 3M Canada exclusive rights within Canada to sell and market Greenjacket(TM) Wildlife Outage Mitigation Systems (Greenjacket).    "We are always looking for ways to expand our portfolio and working with small businesses is a great opportunity for that," said Bill Boyce, Alberta regional director, 3M Canada. "With almost 20 per cent of power outages resulting from animal interference, Greenjacket ensures 3M is better equipped to meet our customers' energy needs."    Greenjacket is a long-term system solution to prevent power outages from bird and animal contact in substations. This tight-fitting insulated material is tailored to specific energized equipment. Not only does Greenjacket improve system reliability but also reduces maintenance costs by preventing power outages.    "We are thrilled to work with an industry leader like 3M," said Al Gourley, Cantega Chairman & CEO. "With its strong reputation for high-quality products and large customer base, this alliance will help position our company to expand both nationally and internationally."    Greenjacket is quick and easy to install and comes in any shape or size ensuring the right fit every time. Greenjacket poses no threat to the environment and is highly UV resistant. Cantega specialists develop a custom solution for each substation using a thorough three-step process. A representative assesses substation wildlife risks then designs and manufactures solutions and installs the Greenjacket.    3M has been involved in the electrical market since the 1950s and through innovation and alliances continually improves its product line to meet customer needs. 3M's electrical markets division supplies the utility industry with a wide variety of products from splicing and termination to safety and protection.    Photos available upon request.    About 3M Canada:    Established in 1951, 3M Canada Company was one of the first international subsidiaries opened by 3M and remains one of the largest. 3M Canada's head office and original manufacturing site is in London, Ontario where approximately 1,000 of the company's 1,950 employees work. Other Ontario plants are located in Toronto, Brockville, and Perth with one in Morden, Manitoba. 3M has sales offices in major cities nationwide and a national service network to support customers.    About Cantega:    Founded in 2001 by a senior power lineman with 25 years' experience in the industry, CANTEGA(TM) Technologies Inc. is a private company based in Edmonton, Alberta that services power systems in several provinces. For more information on Cantega visit www.cantega.com.             /CONTACT: Sarah Tattersall, 3M Canada, 1-800-265-1840 x 6035, setattersall@mmm.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 10:02 ET (14:02 GMT)

Headline: MARKET TALK: Telefonica EU Fine Disproportioned -Caja Madrid
Story: 1126 GMT [Dow Jones]--Telefonica (TEF) shares trade +0.4% at EUR16.51, little moved following a well-flagged EU fine for abuse of its dominant position in the Spanish broadband market. The EUR151.9M fine equals about 1% of Telefonica's Ebitda, says Caja Madrid's Nahun Sanchez. "I don't know what criteria the EU has used when coming up with this number. This is a disproportioned fine," Sanchez says. "There's a confrontation here between national and EU legislation. The only thing Telefonica did was apply Spanish law." Keeps stock at neutral, EUR16 target. Headline: : Canadian Real Estate Investment Trust Announces Closing Of Unit Financing Of $78.125 Million>REF.UN.T
Story: TORONTO, ONTARIO--(CCNMatthews - July 4, 2007) -  Canadian Real Estate Investment Trust ("CREIT") (TSX:REF.UN) of Toronto, Ontario today announced that it has closed the previously announced sale of 2,500,000 Units at a price of $31.25 per Unit for aggregate gross proceeds of $78,125,000 to a syndicate of underwriters led by RBC Capital Markets on a bought-deal basis.    The Units have not been registered under the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, and may not be offered or sold in the United States absent registration or an applicable exemption from the registration requirements.    CREIT is a real estate investment trust focussed on accumulating a portfolio of high-quality real estate assets and delivering the benefits of real estate ownership to Unitholders. The primary benefit is a reliable and, over time, increasing monthly cash distribution. CREIT owns a real estate portfolio of over 140 retail, office and industrial properties. Headline: Nippon Ham To Hike Retail Product Prices 10% - Nikkei
Story: OSAKA (Nikkei)--Nippon Meat Packers Inc. (2282.TO), or Nippon Ham, said Wednesday that it will raise prices on about 500 retail products, such as ham, sausages and frozen pizza, by an average of 10% effective Sept. 1, The Nikkei reported in its Thursday morning edition.   This will mark its second straight year of price increases, following the roughly 10% effective hike implemented in June 2006. The company plans to increase shipment prices or reduce net weight.   Nippon Ham says its raw materials costs have increased because of pork prices rising about 10% on the year this fiscal year. Details, such as specific hikes, will be fleshed out soon.   Itoham Foods Inc. (2284.TO) and Marudai Food Co. (2288.TO) are among the others said to also be considering raising prices.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 13:36 ET (17:36 GMT)

Headline: Steel Partners To Continue Bull-Dog Tender Offer -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--U.S. investment fund Steel Partners is expected to continue its tender offer for Bull-Dog Sauce Co. (2804.TO) stock beyond Wednesday, which the condiment maker has set as a deadline for the fund to drop its takeover bid, sources familiar with the matter said the same day, the Nikkei reported in its Wednesday evening edition.   Steel Partners filed a petition with the Tokyo District Court in June seeking a temporary injunction against Bull-Dog's plan to block the fund's bid, saying it violated the principle of treating all shareholders equally. The court rejected the request on June 28. Steel Partners immediately appealed the decision to the Tokyo High Court, and a decision is expected shortly.   A Steel Partners official said Wednesday the fund is proceeding with the tender offer and that it expects a favorable decision from the high court. The fund has no reason to drop the takeover bid before the appeal is decided, he added.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 01:05 ET (05:05 GMT)

Headline: =WSJ:Coke Confirms Mulling Bid For Cadbury Schweppes' Snapple
Story: By Aaron O. Patrick and Jason Singer     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     Coca-Cola Co. (KO) has approached several private equity funds involved in bidding for Cadbury Schweppes PLC's (CSG) U.S. drinks business about buying Cadbury's Snapple iced tea brand, according to people familiar with the situation.   If successful, such a purchase could significantly expand Coke's range of non-soda drinks, a key priority for the company which wants to increase its presence in the fast-growing market for healthy drinks, juices and waters.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal's Web site, WSJ.com)   Speaking in Geneva Wednesday, Coke Chief Executive E. Neville Isdell told a Reuters reporter that the company was evaluating a bid for Snapple. "That is a valuation that we undertake - whether it (Snapple) is of interest to us, or whether we can do it on our own," he said, according to Reuters.   A Coke spokesman in Atlanta confirmed Isdell's comments and declined to comment further.   Two groups of private-equity firms have lodged bids to buy Cadbury's drinks business. The two groups of private equity firms have already heard presentations from Cadbury management and their second-round bids are due by next week, a person close to the matter said. A decision is expected by the end of July.   The sale of the U.S.-based drinks business is expected to bring in more than $10 billion for Cadbury, which said it would shed the business in March after activist investor Nelson Peltz purchased a stake in the company.   Peltz bought Snapple in 1997 for $300 million and sold it, along with some other brands, three years later to Cadbury for $1.45 billion.   London-based Cadbury said in March it split in two, separating its U.S. drinks business - which includes Dr. Pepper, 7 Up and Snapple among other brands - from its candy business which includes Trident gum and Cadbury dairy milk chocolate and others.   A person familiar with the situation said Coke hasn't approached Cadbury about buying Snapple, and Cadbury had no plans to sell the brand separately from the rest of its drinks business.   But Coke has had talks with some of the private equity firms bidding for the drinks unit about buying Snapple from them, according to people familiar with the situation. The private equity firms aren't leaning toward a pre-sale, but given recent market wobbles, if such a deal would make a purchase easier and comes at an attractive price, they would consider it.   For Coke, Snapple would be the latest in its drive to broaden its drinks portfolio. In May, Atlanta-based Coke agreed to pay $4.1 billion for Energy Brands Inc., which makes vitamin-enhanced water, in the strongest sign yet of its intention to grow its business outside its core soda brands. It was the largest deal in Coke's history.     -By Aaron O. Patrick and Jason Singer, The Wall Street Journal   (Betsy McKay in Atlanta contributed to this report)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 14:30 ET (18:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sodexho 9 Mos Revs +3.6% To EUR10.22B >SDX -2-
Story: In a press statement early Wednesday, Sodexho said sales for the first nine months ending May 31 rose to EUR10.22 billion from EUR9.87 billion a year ago.   Sodexho said the company is confident it will meet its full year objectives of organic sales growth over 7% and a 12% rise in operating profit growth, excluding currency impact.   Sodexho's core business of food and facilities management services posted 3.2% growth, or 7.4% growth on a like-for-like basis to EUR9.91 billion as slower growth in Europe dragged on double-digit growth in the region the company calls 'rest of the world' which includes the Middle East, Africa and Latin America.   The fast-growing vouchers business grew 19% to EUR323 million from EUR273 million a year ago.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 01:29 ET (05:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 3rd UPDATE:Kidnapped BBC Reporter Johnston Released By Hamas
Story: (Updates with Johnston heading to Jerusalem with U.K. diplomats)   GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip (AP)--U.K. reporter Alan Johnston, looking pale and tired, was released Wednesday after nearly four months in captivity in the Gaza Strip and said it was "fantastic" to be free after an "appalling" ordeal.   The British Broadcasting Corp. correspondent said his captors threatened his life a number of times in various ways but were rarely violent, although they hit him in the final moments before he was released. They kept him in solitary confinement throughout his captivity and at one point, chained his hands and ankles for a 24-hour period. He also said he got sick from the food.   "It is just the most fantastic thing to be free," Johnston said in a telephone interview with the BBC hours after he was freed. "It was an appalling experience, as you can imagine, 16 weeks kidnapped, sometimes, occasionally, quite terrifying and frightening," he said, speaking from the Gaza home of deposed Hamas Prime Minister Ismail Haniyeh.   Shortly afterward, Johnston set off in a convoy for Jerusalem in the company of U.K. diplomats, a U.K. consular official said.   As recently as last week, Johnston's life appeared to be in serious peril when the group holding him posted a video on a militant Web site in which the journalist appeared to be wearing an explosives belt that he said his captors would detonate it if there were an attempt to free him.   While he was in captivity, a civil war raged on the streets of Gaza around him and Israel was bombarding Palestinian militants with airstrikes.   "It became almost hard to imagine normal life again," Johnston told the BBC in a steady and composed voice. "And I literally dreamt many many times of being free and always woke up back in that room and now it really is over and it is indescribably good to be out," he said.   "I didn't know where it was going to end," he said. "I think I'm OK after an extraordinary level of stress and psychological pressure for a long, long time ... I probably got out of it as well as I could have."   He said he had a radio throughout most of his captivity and was able to follow the support and interest in his case, which was "a huge psychological boost."   Johnston was kidnapped by a shadowy, little-known group known as the Army of Islam from a Gaza City street on March 12 and held far longer than any other foreign reporter in Gaza.   After his release, he was taken to the home of Haniyeh in Gaza City's Shati refugee camp. Before entering, Johnston told an Associated Press reporter, "I'm OK, really, I'm OK."   Television footage showed him sitting beside Haniyeh and surrounded by other Hamas officials. He thanked Haniyeh and Hamas.   The BBC also reported Johnston had spoken to his father since his release.   Asked by Al-Jazeera television whether he would return to Gaza, which he had covered for three years, Johnston said: "After many months of kidnapping, I think I need a break."   Television footage showed Johnston emerging from a building in Gaza surrounded by a throng of armed Palestinian men and escorted into a waiting car while cameras flashed around him.   There was no immediate comment from Johnston's former captors.   Hamas had demanded Johnston's freedom since it violently seized control of Gaza last month, in an apparent bid to curry favor with the West.   But a senior Hamas leader, Mahmoud Zahar, denied that Hamas acted in an effort to improve its relations with the West, which is boycotting the Islamic group over its violently anti-Israel ideology.   "We didn't work to receive favors from the British government. We did this because of humanitarian concern, and to achieve a government aim to extend security to all without fear," Zahar said.   On Tuesday, Hamas gunmen took positions around the Army of Islam's stronghold, stepping up the pressure to secure his release. Hamas officials said they were tightening the siege on Johnston's kidnappers and would spare no efforts to free him.   Still it was not immediately clear why Johnston's captors chose to release him at this time or under what specific terms he was freed, but Hamas said there would be no crackdown on the Army of Islam.   Ayman Taha, a Hamas spokesman, said Johnston's captors had responded positively to recent efforts by tribal and religious leaders to end Johnston's ordeal. Taha said the Army of Islam would not be dismantled or disarmed in return for freeing the reporter.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 04, 2007 00:43 ET (04:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Audi 1H China, Hong Kong Deliveries +27% At 49,267 Cars -2-
Story: Audi said it delivered 45,571 locally produced cars to customers in China in the first six months, up 23% on the year. Headline: MARKET TALK: HSBC Upgrades Nokia Target Price To EUR23
Story: 0739 GMT [Dow Jones] HSBC upgrades Nokia (NOK) target price to EUR23 from EUR19.6 noting that medium-term the handset maker will show positive handset volumes, as well as margin improvements in its Nokia Siemens Networks joint venture. However, reiterates a neutral rating due to short- term volatility in the market and integration risks from Nokia Siemens Networks. Shares trade +0.5% at EUR21.49.
